The elite Institutes lend their expertise and enrich the course curriculum with Business Data Acumen, Statistics, Machine Learning and Computing, and their contemporary business applications in the Analytics industry. PGDBA‚Äôs unique course structure leverages the industry connect and offers a 6-Month Industry Internship, which provides time to the candidates to prove their mettle in the industry. This has resulted in 70% of the batch securing full time job offers (PPO) with marquee firms like DE Shaw & Co, Mastercard, Amazon, PwC DIAC, Mondelez, McKinsey, and Play Games in the recent years. Over the years, candidates are offered roles in domains like Business Model Analytics, Financial Research, Market Research, Analytics Business Consulting, Deep Learning, Machine Learning, Natural Language Processing, Business Analytics, Risk Analytics, Business Intelligence, Healthcare Analytics, Supply Chain Analytics, Marketing Analytics to name a few. Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Categories Articles Technical A Record, a Code and Twitter Post author By pgdba_admin Post date January 20, 2016 3 Comments on A Record, a Code and Twitter How my first machine learning model was validated by a goal scored a continent away. Ritwik Moghe It was the twenty-eighth day of November 2015. As the strangely balmy day yawned, stretched and gratefully gave way to dusk, several eyes were glued to the actions of one man. The man was slight, had strange spiky hair and a face that might remind many of all those ‚Äòdawgs‚Äô or ‚Äòdealers‚Äô from Breaking Bad. Only a year back, hardly anyone knew of his existence. And today, he was about to etch his name in the annals of footballing history. As he latched on to a pitch perfect through-ball that split the Manchester United defense in half and slotted it in past the oncoming goalkeeper, several things exploded. One of those was the voice of the legendary Martin Tyler as he shouted ‚ÄúVardy! Its Eleven, it‚Äôs Heaven for Jamie Vardy‚Äù ( The goal as it unfolded ). Jamie Vardy, a name most of you might still be unfamiliar with, had broken the English Premier League Record of scoring goals in most number of consecutive matches. He had scored in each of the past eleven games. In the grand scheme of things, the record, in itself might not be much significance. What mattered more was Vardy‚Äôs story. From an amateur player with no ‚Äòproper‚Äô training or facilities and very humble beginnings, he had risen to be the most prolific striker in one of the most competitive leagues around the world. It was a classic fairy-tale. For several amateurs trudging every evening into those muddy football fields and trying to curl it like Carlos, Vardy was hope. So as he was being engulfed by his team-mates after he had scored that crucial record-breaking goal, Vardy was causing another explosion around the world. It was an explosion of hope, of greetings and of admiration. And sitting in our dorm rooms overlooking the ponderous Barrackpore Trunk Road in the quaint campus of ISI Calcutta, a bunch of us fledgling data-scientists of PGDBA captured this joyous explosion. We captured it using Twitter. A graph encapsulating the positive Twitter sentiment about Vardy right after THE GOAL! The problem that we were working on was Opinion Mining through tweets. Billions of tweets are posted every day. These tweets reflect the opinions or sentiments of the users about various topics. For instance, a tweet like ‚ÄúI love Apple #Iphone6‚Äù might reflect the user‚Äôs positive sentiment about the company Apple. A study of several such tweets about a particular subject or company can provide valuable insights to the company about the general public opinion about themselves. We were analyzing the Twitter sentiment about various current and upcoming football stars. Our aim was to identify the next big star, the one who would eclipse Messi and attain the ultimate pinnacle of fame by someday being the brand ambassador of Tata Motors! Our observation about Vardy and his big day was a mere microcosm of a bigger project where we analyzed over one million tweets about 10 players obtained over a period of one month. The analysis began with mining tweets about the particular players. The tweets were obtained from an API using Python. Relevant meta-data like the location of the user and the time-stamp of the tweet was extracted along with the text of the tweet. The text of the tweet was then converted into a Term-Document Frequency Matrix (TDF). Now only a year ago, all that I could I have thought of on hearing ‚ÄòTerm-Document Frequency Matrix‚Äô would have been Neo in his slick glasses staring into some green numbers floating Chinese-style on an antique nineties monitor! But TDF is way simpler than that. All it does is that it creates a table. Each row is a tweet. All the words observed in all the tweets that we are studying make up the columns. Consider this example for clarity- Thus each word is now a feature and each tweet a data-point. We then used a Machine Learning technique called Maximum Entropy Classifier in R to classify each tweet or data-point into one of the three categories: Positive, Neutral or Negative. (I could get into the details of the work, about why we went for supervised classification approach, about why MaxEnt works best for Text Classification etc. But since I‚Äôm trying to make this article tractable for someone with no prior analytics experience I stop by providing a link to another blog about our detailed work. ( A detailed report of our project ) Now this process was carried out for all the tweets about all the different players. The prevalent sentiment about a particular player was given by the difference between the number of positive and negative tweets (which was also normalized). Doing this helped us observe several interesting trends in the data. Consider the comparative study of sentiments about Neymar, Ronaldo and Harry Kane over November 2015. Also, have a look at how the sentiment about Harry Kane varied across countries. Such analysis has huge potential applications. Imagine how Tottenham Hotspurs, the club which Harry Kane plays for could maximize their profits by opening more ‚ÄòSpurs Stores‚Äô in South Africa where Kane is way more popular (green) as compared to say Australia where he is clearly notorious (red). Are you an executive at EA Sports and want to decide whom to have on the cover of FIFA 16? Just mine sentiment on twitter and viola, you‚Äôll see that Neymar would be a way better choice than Kane. So this was all about our project on Twitter sentiment about football superstars. This project was a part of our course called Computing for Data Sciences at ISI Kolkata. All of our fellow mates from PGDBA have also worked on several such (hopefully: P) interesting projects. Some of them will share their stories with you on this blog as well. Vardy and his record holds a special place in our hearts. He was the perfect muse for demonstrating the effectiveness of our model. When you‚Äôve come up with your first ‚ÄòReal‚Äô model, the true test of the model happens when you see it work in real life on a completely unexpected scale. That meteoric rise in Vardy‚Äôs sentiment at 5.55 pm BST, right after he had scored the crucial goal proved to us beyond doubt that our model worked! So, I sign off with a link to that moment when Vardy smashed a record, the moment when people around the world celebrated the dawn of a new star, and the moment when our model was validated! Cheers! About - PGDBA - IIMC|IITKGP|ISI-K PGDBA ‚Äì IIMC|IITKGP|ISI-K Home About Prospects of PGDBA Curriculum Blog AINA ‚Äì Magazine AINA ‚Äì 1.0 AINA ‚Äì 2.0 AINA ‚Äì 3.0 AINA ‚Äì 4.0 Aspirants Corner About What is PGDBA? PGDBA stands for Post Graduate Diploma in Business Analytics ( PGDBA website ), probably the first two year full time course in India, jointly offered by Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta ; Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata and Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur . PGDBA has been started with the philosophy that data is the new oil in this century. With an abundance of data, driving a business successfully and effectively is becoming a tricky aspect. Recent surveys suggest that big data could create $300 billion in value in healthcare alone each year; clever use of location data across industries could capture $600 billion in consumer surplus. Conversely, poor data management can cost up to 35% of a business‚Äôs operating revenue. While the possibility and ability to capture and store the ocean of data has grown up to overwhelming levels, but the right use of techniques to extract ‚Äòinformation‚Äô from these data sets has not been keeping pace with the demands of the industry, and there continues to be a worrying skill shortage across all sectors. More specifically saying, crunching data to generate necessary business insights requires a strong hold on Statistics, Technology and Business simultaneously. The requirement is so rare that the industry hardly sees individuals having the amalgamation of all of these three crucial skills in the domain of Business Analytics. To cater to this need, PGDBA has been built based on three pillars: Math and Statistics, Technology and Business, as clear from the expertise of the parenting institutes. This course offers four semester with an introductory pre-semester. It is true that two years is not adequate enough to generate data scientists and one can hardly scratch the surface of Machine learning and Data mining, but the unique combination of this course gives it a distinct identity which unravels endless opportunities to the participants: Financial analysis, Consultancy, PhD in Machine Learning, R&D, entrepreneurship to build data-driven startups‚Ä¶you name it! Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Category: Technical Categories Articles Experiences Technical Joka Library to Paris ‚Äì A Data Science Crusade Post author By pgdba_admin Post date September 7, 2016 No Comments on Joka Library to Paris ‚Äì A Data Science Crusade A peek into Team Tabs, one of the three teams representing India at DSG. It was a crisp Friday morning and I was seated comfortably in the plush IIMC library. The PGDBA semester was well underway, assignments were raining thick and fast‚Ä¶life was busy‚Ä¶life was good and I was brimming with excitement. I had only just begun working on a competition, which had started 4 days ago on June 14th 2016. It was an inter-university data-science competition called the Data Science Game . With so many constraints such as limited number of submissions in a day and final selection of only one team from a college, it was, by all means the ‚Äúbig deal‚Äù and a glance at the list of competing universities showed us some tough nuts. There were the usual suspects i.e. Stanford, Cambridge, Oxford et al., supplemented by a host of premier universities from across the world. Certainly our team of four from first-ever batch of PGDBA, though no novices, were far from being among the best in the world‚Ä¶ or were they? And so we ‚Äì Team Tabs ‚Äì prepared a starting output, clicked on the ‚ÄòMake Submission‚Äô button and waited with a muted yet expectation-laced anxiety that any Kaggler worth his salt would be familiar with and then this image popped up on our screen: Most authors describe moments like these with the cliche ‚ÄòThere was a moment of silence followed by‚Ä¶.‚Äô I discovered that they were quite wrong‚Ä¶as my uncontrollable Hagrid-like laughter filled the breadth of the IIM Calcutta library, defiant of the several bemused yet stern glares that were pointed in my direction! Second in the whole world! Irrespective of its ephemerality, irrespective of the pains required to maintain it or the challenges that we were about to face in the coming three weeks ‚Äì it was a moment of reckoning for us, a moment to cherish, a moment to savour. Yet, when I look back I can say with certainty that it was at this point I started believing that international glory wasn‚Äôt beyond our reach. What followed were some of the most gruelling days of my life. Over the next three weeks, we went on to learn and implement Deep Learning (Convolutional Neural Networks) algorithms for image classification. We travelled to multiple universities in a quest for servers to run these algorithms. We learnt, we toiled, we toiled hard and we thrived. When the competition ended, we were the top team from India ‚Äì Yes! Our hard work and perseverance led to us being the Rank 1 Indian team . We were among the 20 teams from around the world selected to travel to Paris for the final phase of the competition and folks, as you read this article, we‚Äôre on the flight journey towards the finals of the competition in Paris, to be held on 9th September. What fills me with even more delight is that not just us, but three teams from India have made it to the final 20 ‚Äì one each from IIM Calcutta-Team Tabs, IIT Kharagpur and ISI Kolkata- The Frequentists (in their ranking order). India has made its presence felt in this 2nd edition of Data Science Game and interestingly enough, all the three institutes are what together constitute PGDBA! It is encouraging to see that three Indian teams have proved themselves worthy of being the global top 20 when 146 teams from 28 countries participated and showed their mettle in this grueling competition. The competition contained an image classification problem. A set of images were given, which had to be classified into four categories. The problem at hand could have been done in various ways. We decided to use deep learning as a lot of interesting work is being done around it and it‚Äôs one of the most advanced techniques currently available. We had a basic knowledge about it and developed more understanding as we moved along. The process of compiling and executing codes went on and we worked hard every single day. The machine learning algorithms take time to execute and with limited computing power at our disposal and time constraint of the competition, we ensured that every iota of it was used. As we were fighting neck to neck with all top notch universities across the world, the task was not at all easy and there were a lot of hurdles on the way. The limited computing power slowed us down. Every iteration of the code required a whole day and thus constrained our capacity to experiment with the algorithm. Soon other teams caught up with us on the leaderboard. To wrinkle out the problems we went to IIT-KGP and ISI to gain server access. However, the terminals at both places were preoccupied. As a last resort, we decided to use Amazon Web Services (AWS). AWS was difficult to set-up because of the complex technicalities and as none of us was acquainted with the process, it made our job all the more difficult. We quickly took charge and read about it from the scratch, spending a precious time of 3 days to figure everything out and get it running. In hindsight, it was worth the effort. Our first run in AWS increased the accuracy by 5 % and it all paid off with the jump on the leaderboard. Now that we look at it, a lot of edge was given to us by our PGDBA curriculum. The basics of machine learning and computing were well laid out throughout the course. It enabled us to deep dive into deep learning and comprehend the technical aspects around it. We also consulted with professors for guidance. With Team Tabs standing at 12 in global rankings, we realize that we have learnt a lot on the way, when we were actually working on the problem statement. We will now be competing with some of the top Kagglers in the finals. The finale would certainly provide us with global exposure as we will get a macroscopic view of what‚Äôs happening around the world in the field of data science by interacting with top-notch data analysts spread across the world. Since it‚Äôs a 2-day competition, the dynamics of the game is bound to change. We haven‚Äôt been able to put in continuous concentrated efforts towards the final round owing to the rigorous academic curriculum this semester and us coping up on classes. We do have a lot to cover but we will keep learning new stuff as we have been doing in the past year. Thus a great opportunity for knowledge transfer and networking lies ahead. With everyone‚Äôs hopes in us, we make our journey to Paris, where the final leg of the competition awaits‚Ä¶ along with our fateful turnout in the 2nd Data Science Game competition. About the team ‚Äì ‚ÄúTeam Tabs‚Äù from IIM Calcutta Pranita Khandelwal ‚Äì She completed her graduation (B.Tech.) in Electrical & Electronics Engineering and Masters in Economics from BITS Pilani. Initial interest in statistics and then further exploration of online courses made her pursue a career in the data science field. Ritwik Moghe ‚Äì He is a Mechanical Engineer from IIT Madras. With no coding background in the beginning, he learnt everything after joining the PGDBA program. Avinash Kumar ‚Äì He is a Mechanical Engineer from NIT Jamshedpur and has worked in manufacturing industry prior to joining the PGDBA program. While in college, he participated in some analytics competitions and enhanced his data science skills after studying in the three institutes of PGDBA. Rachit Tripathi ‚Äì He is a Mechanical Engineer from IIT Kanpur. He has worked on multiple projects in Robotics, programing and data handling areas while he was in college. His keen interest in mathematics and computing drove him to join PGDBA. Post author By pgdba_admin Post date August 27, 2016 No Comments on The Best Laid Schemes, of Spiders and Men! What do entropy, linear programming and Riemann surfaces have in common? Puzzled? Now imagine this connection explained by an eccentric speaker in the attire of a French stage magician, with the charm and virtuosity of a storyteller. Cedric Villani, French mathematician, Fields Medal awardee in the year 2010 and famously called by the NewYorker magazine as the ‚ÄòLady Gaga of Mathematics‚Äô delivered a public lecture titled ‚ÄòOf Triangles, Gases, Prices and Men‚Äô at ISI on 26 th August 2016. The second PGDBA batch, currently in its first semester here at ISI, had the opportunity to be present at this intriguing and informative session. Cedric Villani The abstraction and intrigue of Cedric could be assumed from the fact that an introduction to him included a reference to the number of his pets. This abstraction could also be inferred from the title of his talk, which was a play on the title of John Steinbeck‚Äôs famous classic ‚ÄòOf Mice and Men.‚Äô The first slide of his presentation was taken from Tennyson‚Äôs Lady of Shalott. In Cedric‚Äôs own interpretation, the Lady of Shalott, accursed to see the world only through a mirror, was actually an allegory to the mathematician forever accursed to look at reality through his equations! Cedric then said that there are many more unsolved mysteries in Mathematics today than there were a hundred years ago. There are ever so many new problems that keep arising. Then there are those age-old ones that lie in famous mathematicians‚Äô lists of unsolved problems. One such famous unproved hypothesis is the Riemann hypothesis. This led Cedric down the path to explaining Riemann‚Äôs works and then to the first part of the evening‚Äôs presentation ‚Äì ‚Äòtriangles‚Äô. He introduced to the audience Riemann surfaces and how Escher employed curved surfaces in his art. As examples of negative curvatures, he showed images of art installations in museums and models of coral reef. Einstein, with the help of his mathematician colleagues, used Riemann‚Äôs ideas to develop his General Theory of Relativity. Cedric went on to add that, the GPS technology so ubiquitous in the world today has its roots in Riemann‚Äôs works in topology. In a humorous turn of speech, Cedric noted that Riemann was as oblivious to his work being of practical use in 21 st century devices, as modern day GPS users were to Riemann‚Äôs surfaces. An ironic symmetry indeed! At this turn of his presentation, Cedric spoke about how it is equally important for scientists to pursue inspiration and not just utility. He marked out Riemann as someone who was particularly interested in approaching problems in his own unique way. Cedric quoted Poincare who had once said, ‚ÄúMathematics is the art of giving the same name to different things.‚Äù The second part of his talk on ‚Äògases‚Äô started with a description of his visit to Vienna and a search for Boltzmann‚Äôs grave. He said that he stopped to ask a family for a map not expecting them to know Boltzmann, let alone his grave. To his surprise, he was not only directed to the location of the grave but the person also exclaimed Boltzmann‚Äôs equation of entropy, ‚ÄúS=klogW‚Äù! In connection with entropy, he then talked about the Gaussian curve, its ubiquitous nature and its uncanny appearance in many natural systems. He called the study of Probability and Statistics as ‚Äòthe extraordinary adventure of mastering of chance.‚Äô As a matter of coincidence, he discussed a famous problem in his presentation called ‚ÄòBuffon‚Äôs needle‚Äô, which was also discussed in class earlier on the same day with the PGDBA students by their lecturer. Experiments such as coin tosses, Cedric said, are best done in the most careless ways! Then he explained how gases are modeled as billiard balls in collision and when there are many such sufficiently small billiard balls, their velocities are accurately modeled as the Gaussian distribution. As a note, Cedric remarked on the power of this distribution by quoting Sir Francis Galton who once called it the ‚Äòsupreme law of unreason.‚Äô The next part of his presentation was ‚Äòprices‚Äô. Cedric introduced Leonid Kantorovic, the father of linear programming. He explained how math is used to model the optimal allocation of resources. He then strung together ideas from the optimized distribution of resources to the distribution of gas molecules with the least loss of energy. The analogy of prices in linear programming is energy in distribution of gas molecules. This is where Cedric began piecing everything together with the last part of his talk called ‚Äòmen‚Äô. Cedric described how he had happened to meet his collaborators John Lott and Felix Otto. These men put together the ‚Äòtriangles‚Äô, ‚Äògases‚Äô and ‚Äòprices‚Äô and helped Cedric complete his research on how fast gases reach the equilibrium stage described in Boltzmann‚Äôs equation. Cedric was awarded the Fields medal in connection with this research. What would have been an intimidating subject matter coming from volumes over volumes of text, was aptly introduced in a two-hour lecture by Cedric Villani, a master at his trade, a storyteller par excellence, a dinosaur catcher in his childhood dreams and a true ambassador of modern mathematics. In a surprising irony of sorts, apart from the many hidden mysteries in the details of his works, the most apparent mystery is the brooches of spiders that he wears on the lapels of his coat! Categories Articles Technical Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge Post author By pgdba_admin Post date January 31, 2016 1 Comment on Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A brief overview on how I approached a real world healthcare problem via Analytics. Robin Singh Disclaimer : I have tried to restrict technicalities to a minimum in the blog, so as to cater to a wider segment of readers. However, a little awareness about machine learning will make the rest of the post even more comprehensible and hopefully exciting. The healthcare industry is not only huge but also has a tremendous potential for the use of technology and data science. In this post, I will share one of the numerous instances of the use of unconventional analytics to engineer solutions in response to challenges in the field of healthcare. This seemingly complex idea, can be structured and implemented by a combination of machine learning tools and data crunching techniques. The solution proposed here is designed to work with critical patient data in hospitals and raise an alarm when the state of the patient degrades, eventually leading to potentially fatal outcomes. Now the obvious questions, How will such a system help? Can the doctors not monitor patient state physically? Well, it is only possible for a doctor to physically monitor a small number of patients. What if the number of patients is large?. Also, the decision to provide intensive care to patient after an alarm has been raised has monetary and human life impacts. If the alarm can be raised in time, intensive care although expensive, can be provided to the patient. At the backend, the model can be seen as a typical classification machine learning problem . Classification, as the name suggests is a method to categorize data points into predetermined target groups. Numerous algorithms can do classification like Bayesian model, decision tree, random forest, regression etc. We used Random Forest model for the current data set, due to simplicity and ease of implementation. However, the classification method happened to be only the tip of the iceberg. There were many unforeseen challenges ‚Äì primarily due to data coming from the healthcare domain and also computational resource constraints. First, healthcare data is highly erratic and the severity of a measurement varies from person to person. For example, a certain value of a respiratory measurement can be dangerous and life risking for a normal person but normal for a smoker. This poses a fundamental challenge to the accuracy of models built on the healthcare data. Second, the state to be predicted is different from the state whose training data is available. This is slightly difficult to grasp, but lets try. We want to raise an alarm when the patient‚Äôs situation is worsening from normal and approaching mortality but still the patient has time. However, the training dataset has information on the actual mortality/no-mortality. Using the training data to learn will imply making an approximation. The third challenge comes from implementation aspects. The prediction of no-mortality should be highly reliable as compared to prediction of mortality. The system should be able to predict the no-mortality situations with an accuracy of 99% or above. Accuracy in no-mortality and mortality have a trade-off and hence if we tune the model for high accuracy in no-mortality then the accuracy on mortality is low. Let‚Äôs take a moment to think about the methodology again. What can we observe? The predictive model seems to be replicating logic similar to a real doctor. In fact, the very idea of machine learning is to train the machines to apply logic like human beings do. For example, using the past data to learn and take decisions in the future cases, considering trade-offs originating from the decision making process and using the concept of information value to take decision. Discussed above is one example on the use of analytics and artificial intelligence in the healthcare scenario. There are many unexplored applications in the domain, a huge scope for improvement in the existing models and unquantifiable amount of data to process. In the coming years devices based on such models will be a reality and the industry requires many more analyst to cater to the demand. Tags Analytics , Data Sciences , Healthcare Analytics , PGDBA Categories Articles Technical A Record, a Code and Twitter Post author By pgdba_admin Post date January 20, 2016 3 Comments on A Record, a Code and Twitter How my first machine learning model was validated by a goal scored a continent away. Ritwik Moghe It was the twenty-eighth day of November 2015. As the strangely balmy day yawned, stretched and gratefully gave way to dusk, several eyes were glued to the actions of one man. The man was slight, had strange spiky hair and a face that might remind many of all those ‚Äòdawgs‚Äô or ‚Äòdealers‚Äô from Breaking Bad. Only a year back, hardly anyone knew of his existence. And today, he was about to etch his name in the annals of footballing history. As he latched on to a pitch perfect through-ball that split the Manchester United defense in half and slotted it in past the oncoming goalkeeper, several things exploded. One of those was the voice of the legendary Martin Tyler as he shouted ‚ÄúVardy! Its Eleven, it‚Äôs Heaven for Jamie Vardy‚Äù ( The goal as it unfolded ). Jamie Vardy, a name most of you might still be unfamiliar with, had broken the English Premier League Record of scoring goals in most number of consecutive matches. He had scored in each of the past eleven games. In the grand scheme of things, the record, in itself might not be much significance. What mattered more was Vardy‚Äôs story. From an amateur player with no ‚Äòproper‚Äô training or facilities and very humble beginnings, he had risen to be the most prolific striker in one of the most competitive leagues around the world. It was a classic fairy-tale. For several amateurs trudging every evening into those muddy football fields and trying to curl it like Carlos, Vardy was hope. So as he was being engulfed by his team-mates after he had scored that crucial record-breaking goal, Vardy was causing another explosion around the world. It was an explosion of hope, of greetings and of admiration. And sitting in our dorm rooms overlooking the ponderous Barrackpore Trunk Road in the quaint campus of ISI Calcutta, a bunch of us fledgling data-scientists of PGDBA captured this joyous explosion. We captured it using Twitter. A graph encapsulating the positive Twitter sentiment about Vardy right after THE GOAL! The problem that we were working on was Opinion Mining through tweets. Billions of tweets are posted every day. These tweets reflect the opinions or sentiments of the users about various topics. For instance, a tweet like ‚ÄúI love Apple #Iphone6‚Äù might reflect the user‚Äôs positive sentiment about the company Apple. A study of several such tweets about a particular subject or company can provide valuable insights to the company about the general public opinion about themselves. We were analyzing the Twitter sentiment about various current and upcoming football stars. Our aim was to identify the next big star, the one who would eclipse Messi and attain the ultimate pinnacle of fame by someday being the brand ambassador of Tata Motors! Our observation about Vardy and his big day was a mere microcosm of a bigger project where we analyzed over one million tweets about 10 players obtained over a period of one month. The analysis began with mining tweets about the particular players. The tweets were obtained from an API using Python. Relevant meta-data like the location of the user and the time-stamp of the tweet was extracted along with the text of the tweet. The text of the tweet was then converted into a Term-Document Frequency Matrix (TDF). Now only a year ago, all that I could I have thought of on hearing ‚ÄòTerm-Document Frequency Matrix‚Äô would have been Neo in his slick glasses staring into some green numbers floating Chinese-style on an antique nineties monitor! But TDF is way simpler than that. All it does is that it creates a table. Each row is a tweet. All the words observed in all the tweets that we are studying make up the columns. Consider this example for clarity- Thus each word is now a feature and each tweet a data-point. We then used a Machine Learning technique called Maximum Entropy Classifier in R to classify each tweet or data-point into one of the three categories: Positive, Neutral or Negative. (I could get into the details of the work, about why we went for supervised classification approach, about why MaxEnt works best for Text Classification etc. But since I‚Äôm trying to make this article tractable for someone with no prior analytics experience I stop by providing a link to another blog about our detailed work. ( A detailed report of our project ) Now this process was carried out for all the tweets about all the different players. The prevalent sentiment about a particular player was given by the difference between the number of positive and negative tweets (which was also normalized). Doing this helped us observe several interesting trends in the data. Consider the comparative study of sentiments about Neymar, Ronaldo and Harry Kane over November 2015. Also, have a look at how the sentiment about Harry Kane varied across countries. Such analysis has huge potential applications. Imagine how Tottenham Hotspurs, the club which Harry Kane plays for could maximize their profits by opening more ‚ÄòSpurs Stores‚Äô in South Africa where Kane is way more popular (green) as compared to say Australia where he is clearly notorious (red). Are you an executive at EA Sports and want to decide whom to have on the cover of FIFA 16? Just mine sentiment on twitter and viola, you‚Äôll see that Neymar would be a way better choice than Kane. So this was all about our project on Twitter sentiment about football superstars. This project was a part of our course called Computing for Data Sciences at ISI Kolkata. All of our fellow mates from PGDBA have also worked on several such (hopefully: P) interesting projects. Some of them will share their stories with you on this blog as well. Vardy and his record holds a special place in our hearts. He was the perfect muse for demonstrating the effectiveness of our model. When you‚Äôve come up with your first ‚ÄòReal‚Äô model, the true test of the model happens when you see it work in real life on a completely unexpected scale. That meteoric rise in Vardy‚Äôs sentiment at 5.55 pm BST, right after he had scored the crucial goal proved to us beyond doubt that our model worked! So, I sign off with a link to that moment when Vardy smashed a record, the moment when people around the world celebrated the dawn of a new star, and the moment when our model was validated! Cheers! Top professional progression careers: Business Analyst Manager Business Consultant Business intelligence professionals Data Business Analyst Quantitative Analyst/Modeler Academic Progression: The learner with a Postgraduate Diploma in Business Analytics awarded by GMU, Italy can progress onto an MBA from Guglielmo Marconi University, Italy. Guglielmo Marconi University (GMU) promotes the use of innovative learning methodologies and an approach based on the development of interdisciplinary knowledge, skills and competencies with a particular emphasis on the global perspective. It‚Äôs diverse community presently has a total number of 16000 students enrolled in graduate and postgraduate programmes, 300 faculty members and an academic advising team made of more than 200 experts. The University Headquarter is situated in the heart of Rome, near the Vatican City, but the numerous regional and international branches allow both domestic and overseas students to take their final exam and present their thesis/dissertation without leaving their own country or state. Guglielmo Marconi University is approved by ENIC-NARIC. Connect Learning Journey A curriculum designed for working professionals to provide an understanding of business analytics principles and application of data management & data analysis techniques. 03 Months 02 Modules 5+ Live Sessions Download Brochure E-Library Introduction to Business Analytics Management LEARNING OUTCOMES Understand how to critically analyse business data in an organisational decision-making context. Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of business analytics. Demonstrate proper application of data management and data analysis techniques. Application of different statistical data analysis methods and data visualisation techniques to arrive at sound business decisions. Application of Analytics in Business LEARNING OUTCOMES Critical analysis of business problems and the opportunities for organisations to become more analytical and data driven to solve these problems. Demonstrate an understanding of the different categories of analytics. Understand the importance of analytics in marketing and supply chain functions. Understand some of the advanced applications of analytics in business industry. Personalized 1:1 Session with a Learning Advisor Get expert guidance tailored to your learning journey! The Prologue ‚Äì 30 days at Joka The Tales of the Triumvirate Interview Experiences PGDBA 2025-27 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2024-26 Interview experiences PGDBA 2023-25 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2022-24 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2021-23 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2020-22 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2019-21 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2018-20 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2017-19 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2016-18 Interview Experiences Part-1 PGDBA 2016-18 Interview Experiences Part-2 Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA PGDBA 2015-17 Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 2 PGDBA 2015-17 Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 1 PGDBATalks AINA ‚Äì Magazine AINA ‚Äì 1.0 AINA ‚Äì 2.0 AINA ‚Äì 3.0 AINA ‚Äì 4.0 Resources FAQs Tweet Share Pin it PGDBA Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 2 March 3, 2016 pgdba_admin General , Interview Experiences 0 Comments The second round of selection for PGDBA 2016-2018 is just around the corner. So, Madhur Modi is back with yet another compilation of interview experiences of some of our batchmates. This article reflects the diversity of our batch and hopefully the interview experiences shared here will provide the selected aspirants a peek into the kind of questions they are going to face. Happy Reading!! Sailesh Mohanty , B.Tech in Electronics and communications with 3 years of experience in Banking and financial services and an excellent quizzer ‚ÄúI had my interview on the first day so I answered about the separate written test which was held for everyone during the process. There were questions on probability and Bernoulli process, distributions and questions related to formulae. I was also asked about my job experience which primarily focussed upon customer analytics and acquisition. I had left my job and travelled places which I described vividly along with blogs I wrote during the time. The interview also covered current affairs with my opinion about topics related to net neutrality (which was a trending topic at that time) .‚Äù ****** Loveleen Kaur , a fresher in electrical engineering ‚ÄúI had applied using my GRE score and my interview led to questions about my decision to pick this course over general management. There were a lot of HR questions including my introduction and family background. I also faced technical puzzles such as how to increase sales of a petrol pump. Other technical questions were focused on probability, linear algebra and calculus. It was a short interview with questions based on topics on my areas of interest.‚Äù ****** Niten Singh , B.Tech in electrical engineering with 4+ years of experience in IT industry ‚ÄúMy experience is in databases ERP systems. The interview covered questions about my job experience and HR topics. Technical questions were mainly around basics of probability and probability density functions. He also asked about distributions and limit and continuity. I answered what would be my expectations from the course, the work culture of different companies I have worked in, statistics and its uses. It was a diverse interview with a lot of focus on statistics‚Äù ****** Subhra Sardar , B.Tech in IT with around 2.5+ years of software experience and an awesome designer ‚ÄúI have worked on Mainframe computers which hold relevance in analytics so my interview focused on how they are currently prevalent in the industry and how they are slowly migrating to other systems. I also faced technical questions which were based on probability, statistics and permutations. There were times when I faced difficulties solving but the panelists were kind enough to provide me small hints which were enough to find the solution. My interview slot was the last one of the day yet it took 30 minutes to complete. However, the interview was focused both on my job and technical skills.‚Äù ****** Hitesh Dundi, a fresher with B.Tech in EEE ‚ÄúI had a 30-minute-long, quite formal interview. I faced general knowledge based questions, with technical questions mostly based on calculus and coordinate geometry and other topics such as binomial theorem. Since I am a fresher, I was also asked questions about my subjects in college.‚Äù ****** Ramakrishna Ronanki , a mechanical engineer with around 4 years of manufacturing experience ‚ÄúMy interview focussed on my introduction, job experience. They also asked why I wanted to join the course. They delved deep into the topic and also discussed my background and startup which my brother started. There were mathematical questions such as on functions, probability and definition with examples of basic topics such as mutually exclusive events. The interview also covered the questions around the written test which we gave during the interview process‚Äù ****** Akshay Naik , a fresher in computer engineering ‚ÄúMy interview was mainly focused on college related topics including my project which happened to be based on education analytics. Thus my interview was skin deep focused on analytics and college project. I also answered technical questions on statistics and time series. Sometimes I could not answer completely but the panelists gave hints using which led to the solution. Project related questions covered use of statistics in the project, tools and software, sponsors. I was also asked about R programming language and many project specific questions. Technical questions were also based on quadratic equations and binomial theorem, simple and compound interest.‚Äù ****** Chandra Bhanu Jha, a mechanical engineer with 11 months of IT experience and a talented guitarist ‚ÄúThey asked about job description, my profile and college. Even with only 11 months of experience, the panelist questioned exhaustively on my job including job specific questions (physics simulations and SHM, its assumptions and characteristics and physical significance). Another major question was why analytics? I also answered queries about my undergraduate paper which was on neural networks, how they can be applied in the field of mechanical engineering. I gave an overview of the management related subjects during my college such as operations research, optimization and finance. Thus my interview was mainly filled with drilling questions on my job profile, SHM, mechanical engineering and college paper‚Äù ****** Manaswi Veligatla, B.Tech in Instrumentation engineering with 10 months of experience in petrochemical sector ‚ÄúMy interview began around my job description and job profile and part time financial work. This took the interview towards the methods to analyze data. I faced only a couple of mathematical questions on integrations. They also questioned why I want to take PGDBA and applied using GRE score. I described how I had interests in mathematics and was planning to pursue MS in the same but found this course in India better suited to my profile. Overall my interview was mainly focused on my job experience and finance.‚Äù ****** Riju Bhattacharya , B.Tech in Production engineering with 1.25 years of experience in pure-play analytics ‚ÄúApart from the questions related to why I wanted to join this course on analytics and my introductions, I answered about my job profile in analytics and projects completed so far. Having worked in both retail and healthcare analytics I was quizzed on statistical knowledge, data mining problems and mathematical questions from the written test. Overall my interview was focussed on how this course would benefit my progression as an analytics professional‚Äù Analytics Data Sciences Experience IIM Calcutta IIT KGP Interview ISI PGDBA PI Student Life students Post navigation Next Article PGDBA Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 1 Previous Article PGDBA ‚Äì Second batch arrives Related Articles Interview Experiences PGDBA 2025-27 Interview Experiences Greetings, Future PGDBA Achievers! Full name Rajat Gupta College IIT Kharagpur Specialization B.Tech + M.Tech (Dual) in Civil Engineering Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (12) Organization(Name) Oceanergy Designation Structural Engineer Work Experience Background Oil and Gas Interview Location city Mumbai Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 5 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions None Maths/Stats questions https://qr.ae/TWILlI GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) No Is the interview stressful? No Tips for Written Exam https://www.exambazaar.com/blogpost/pgdba-course-exam Tips to fill Application Form https://www.exambazaar.com/blogpost/pgdba-course-exam Personal Interview https://www.exambazaar.com/blogpost/pgdba-course-exam Any other interaction post-interview ‚Äì Full name Anadi Vashist College Hindu College, University of Delhi Specialization M.Sc. Statistics Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (23) Organization(Name) EXL Services Private Limited Designation Senior Business Analyst Work Experience Background Analytics/Consulting Interview Location city Delhi Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 4 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions Statistics Maths/Stats questions 1)MLE of Uniform distribution. X~U(0, theta) and then X~U(-theta, theta) 2) Hypothesis testing: How to formulate hypothesis? Composite null and alternate hypothesis testing? 3) Method of Moments Estimation 4)Linear Regression: OLS estimation and how to obtain normal equations? GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) No Is the interview stressful? Yes Tips for Written Exam Revise Mathematics of 11th and 12th. Start with basics, Ncert and RD Sharma for concepts and formulae. Tips to fill Application Form Nothing too specific. Personal Interview Revise Graduation Courses relevant to the course. Any other interaction post-interview ‚Äì Full name Shubham Sureka College BIT Mesra Specialization BE Information Technology Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (36) Organization(Name) Olympeo Infrastructure LLP, ZS Associates, Snapdeal Designation Assistant Manager, Decision Analytics Associate, Business Analyst 2 Work Experience Background Marketing/Advertising, Analytics/Consulting Interview Location city Delhi Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 4 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions Few questions were there about my project I did at Snapdeal. I had to explain them the project. There were questions on Joins in SQL (some random sample data and they asked me to get a result). I remember briefly the question. Q1: There were some tickets along with their timestamp (created time stamp). Against each row, there was a column highlighting if the ticket if closed or not. Also, another columns showcasing the time when the ticket was closed. I had to find the maximum time taken by a ticket to get closed. Same for minimum. Also, how many tickets are still not closed? All using joins.Solution: Just do a left join on the ticket id and Mark the condition as closing date greater then opening date. Then calculate the difference in the time stamps (Closing-Open). Then group by functionality can be used to get the results.The discussion on this went for around 10-15 minutesKnowledge about Left Join and Inner Join was sufficient. They also made me write sub nested sub queries. The level was not very difficult. Maths/Stats questions What is correlation? Draw some examples? Basic idea about regression? They made me draw some graphs of some functions. They were bit tricky, but doable. GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) Yes Is the interview stressful? Maybe Tips for Written Exam Cat series (IMS or CL for English, DI, LR and few Maths questions) Do prepare Maths NCERT Miscellaneous exercises. In case you feel difficulty in some topics, brush up on JEE notes. Tips to fill Application Form Focus on what your work experience is. This will help you keep the interview in control. Don‚Äôt put lot of different things. Your form should be crisp and clear. For freshers and people with non analytics background try to do at least one project or course. This certainly shows that you‚Äôre interested for the course. Try to connect business and Analytics together. You can always quote some examples from your work experience or studies. This will convince them that you understand how analytics can be integrated in various business fields and will get you a brownie point üòâ Personal Interview I read all the techniques through YouTube. I prepared my CV points pretty well and to some extent I was able to keep the discussion around that. Jb statistics be a good resource for few basics. Any other interaction post-interview ‚Äì Full name Srijan Gupta College Pandit Deendayal Petroleum University, Gandhinagar Specialization B.Tech in Chemical Engineering Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (18) Organization(Name) Defence, L&T Limited Designation Sectional-in-charge Work Experience Background Manufacturing Interview Location city Delhi Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 5 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions What is analytics? How do you relate yourself to analytics? Why is analytics a buzz word these days? Maths/Stats questions I was asked to solved an integral with cubic expression in the denominator. It reduced to a fraction of linear and quadratic expressions upon partial fraction. I forgot the formula for the standard quadratic at that time, so showed the panelist the expression formed. GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) Yes Is the interview stressful? Yes Tips for Written Exam NCERT mathematics is a great source for fundamental mathematics, and that easily got me through 75% of the maths section. The remaining question needed an extensive deductibility of NCERT concepts. Some standard AIEEE (JEE Main) book might be helpful. Do cover calculus portion judiciously and diligently. Tips to fill Application Form We were asked to provide our extensive background, including why you want to join this course, and hobbies. To answer the first question, I related the course to my long term goal and it made the whole process a cakewalk. Hobbies is something that should be genuine and something that you really are passionate about. the panelists can easily sense when a person is cooking up, and then they can grill you down even further. Personal Interview TIME mock interviews were a great help. To supplement the analytics domain knowledge, linear algebra basic concepts, normal distribution fundamentals, engineering level project management or operation optimization topics like decision tree and transportation problems might come in handy. Any other interaction post-interview ‚Äì Full name Immidisetty Anudeep College IIT Kharagpur Specialization Civil Engineering Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (12) Organization(Name) Wipro Ltd. Designation Project Engineer Work Experience Background Software/IT and ITES Interview Location city Bangalore Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 4 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions 1. Why do you want to do PGDBA? 2. Applications of analytics in business. 3. How can you use analytics to develop the business of an MSME type industry Maths/Stats questions 1. Give real-life examples for Poisson Distribution. What are mean and SD of Poisson Distribution. Ans. Accidents occurring on a road, Number of Calls arriving at a call centre. Mean = variance = Œª. 2. Where does Normal Distribution meet X-axis Ans. At infinity. He tried to confuse me here. 3. Properties of Normal Distribution Ans. Bell curve, uncorrelated implies independence, 2 parameter distribution defined by its mean and sd. Generally fits most practical situations. 4. Differentiability of abs(x) Ans. Differentiable everywhere except 0. 5. How do you say when a function is continuous. Ans. When left limit = right limit = f(x) for all x. 6. How do you say if a function is differentiable? Ans. When left derivative = right derivative. GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) No Is the interview stressful? No Tips for Written Exam Arun Sharma ‚Äì Reading Comprehension and Logical reasoning books Tips to fill Application Form Be true. Do not overstate as it may back fire. Write only those points to which you can answer, discard those which you are not sure of. Try to connect your goals to business analytics. Personal Interview 1. medium.com 2. Probability and Statistics by WW Hines and Montgomery Any other interaction post-interview Also, they asked some Civil Engineering related questions as I was a Civil Engineering Graduate. Full name Karthikeya R College IIT Kharagpur Specialization B.Tech in Agricultural and Food Engineering Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (11) Organization(Name) PhonePe Designation Business Analyst Work Experience Background Analytics/Consulting Interview Location city Bangalore Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 4 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions Hypothesis Testing, p-value etc. Maths/Stats questions Asked to Prove Pythagoras theorem [Draw the perpendicular from the right vertex to hypotenuse and use Similar triangles theorem] GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) Yes Is the interview stressful? Maybe Tips for Written Exam I would recommend practicing from Previous year JEE Mains Questions (Arihant) [only intersection topics], any popular test series (to improve speed). Tips to fill Application Form Write what is relevant to the professional background. Most of my interview was stressed over what was written. Personal Interview Questions on Matrix Linear Transformations, Mathematical Induction, Applications of Analytics in Payments Industry followed by Why PGDBA, General Awareness Questions, etc. Any other interaction post-interview ‚Äì Full name KOLLI PARASURAM College NIT Bhopal Specialization B.tech in Electronics and Communication Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (33) Organization(Name) Bharti Airtel Designation Assistant Manager Work Experience Background Telecommunication Interview Location city Delhi Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 5 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions Nothing related to above topics. The panel asked me about work i do in my company. Then they asked if i know coding. I said no. Then they asked what i know in technical. I said Mathematics. Then interviewer asked what in mathematics and gave examples like statistics, probability. I said i am ok with any of the topic. Then they asked if i am comfortable with random variables. I said Yes and from that point interview started. Maths/Stats questions Q1. Find probability mass function of discrete random variable at one point giving its value at all other points? Ans:- Sum of probabilities is 1. So subtracted the sum of probabilities of all other points from 1 to get required answer. This took a good amount of time for calculation and gave correct answer. Q2. Plot the probability mass function of above discrete random variable? Ans:- I drawn it correctly. Q3. Find the probability of a continuous discrete random variable to lie between 1 and 2 giving cumulative distribution function (cdf)? Ans:- If cfd=f(x) then integrate f(x)dx with between lower limit 1 and higher limit 2. I did not solve it completely i drawn the graph and shaded area and wrote the integration form. Interviewer seen the equation and said it correct and not needed to solve completely. Q4. Find expected value of expected value of discrete random variable in first question? Ans:- summation of xf(x) from x=-infinity to x=infinity where f(x) is pmf in terms of random variable x. I answered it correctly. Q5. Find the expected value for the continuous random variable in third question? Ans:- Integration of xf(x) from x=-infinity to x=infinity where f(x) is cdf I answered it correctly. Then he asked if i know about situations of two random variables. I said i can do but only to basic level. Interviewer said he will ask basic level questions only and asked. Q6. Joint pdf of two random variable X and Y is given and asked to find marginal cdf of y where 0<x<y<1. Ans:- Integrate the x from 0 to y for the joint pdf to get marginal cdf in term of y. I answered it correctly. Q7. Find the probability of the function now? Ans:- We have to integrate the maginal cdf in y for its limits 0 to 1 where we get answer as 1. I got confused about the lower limit of integration here weather 0 or x. I took a bit of time in thinking and expressed doubt put x but he said it wrong then changed to 0. Sir( interviewer) later gave reason for it. Q8. Draw the plot of the joint pdf region? Ans:- I drawn the region 0<x<y<1 and shaded region on XY axis correctly. GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) Yes Is the interview stressful? No Tips for Written Exam I did not read anything specific just went through my +2 Math textbook Agarwal that to only for additional topics to CAT like Integration, Differentiation,Vectors and Matrices Tips to fill Application Form Follow the rules prescribed correctly. Personal Interview I watched 3Blue1Brown youtube videos on Linear Algebra. Can study other topics also from 3Blue1Brown channel. Advanced Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig. Very good book especially for Probability and Statistics. This is the book i followed during my interview preparation. Any other interaction post-interview They asked why this course and how i use this knowledge. That‚Äôs it. Full name Hemanthkumar E College Amrita School of Engineering Specialization mechanical Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (20) Organization(Name) Infosys limited Designation Systems Engineer Work Experience Background Software/IT and ITES, Analytics/Consulting Interview Location city Bangalore Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 4 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions Explain entropy in decision tree. Explain logistics regression. Maths/Stats questions Explain type 1 and type 2 error. What is precision and recall. What is F1 score . GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) No Is the interview stressful? No Tips for Written Exam I went through 40 year paper solved iit JEE mathematics Amit M Agarwal Tips to fill Application Form Give more importance on those topics which you are comfortable in. For instance, I want the interviewers to ask questions from my work experience so I wrote about my work in the application form. Personal Interview I went through ncert math book. For data science related topics, I analytics Vidya website was helpful. Any other interaction post-interview ‚Äì Full name Sakshi Nagori College IIT Madras Specialization B.Tech in Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (11) Organization(Name) LnT Defence Designation Design Engineer Work Experience Background Oil and Gas Interview Location city Delhi Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 5 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions What is Linear Regression? How do we ensure minimum distance between estimated and actual points (Basically wanted me to talk about RMS method) Showed me a graph for non-linear relationship between variables and asked me about how would i approach finding a regression of such variables. Maths/Stats questions Logical Questions on Inference: Logical Consequence of Negation of a statement GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) Yes Is the interview stressful? Yes Tips for Written Exam I solved only last years‚Äô question papers seriously and it helped. Solving the NCERTs would be of great help too Tips to fill Application Form Think carefully about the hobbies that you would be asked to write. They ask questions regarding that. Personal Interview They asked me a lot of current affairs questions like Insolvency and Bankruptcy Bill. Be prepared with your resume, work experience and educational background Any other interaction post-interview ‚Äì Full name Murali Krishna College IIT Madras Specialization BTech Mechanical Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (23) Organization(Name) Citi Designation officer Work Experience Background BFSI/Finance Interview Location city Bangalore Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 4 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions not specifically.It will be good if you have a brief idea of what those terms are and what is the current trend. Maths/Stats questions many of the question asked were based on my maths courses in my UG (linear algebra, Differential equations, calculus). The question are based on the answer u give for the last questions and related to what u have done. below are the some of the question asked: 1. Basic idea of how different graphs look Ex; draw graph of e^(sinx) and why the graph behaves.what is min and max. how do u calculate 2.write the differential equation of whose solution is e^(sinx) (equation can be one degree or two degree) ‚Äì you can differential the equation twice and form a equation 3. Types of the distribution (like possion,binomial‚Ä¶).what is mean,medain,mode .some probability question 4. what are eigen vectors and values? How many eigen values can 3*3 matrix have? 5. some basic question were asked on core course (Mechanical engineering) 6. question on parabola..which country has a parabola shape? 7. capital of Austria? () some Hr questions‚Ä¶tell me about this yourself? why do u want to apply for this course 8. question of projects if ur experienced GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) Yes Is the interview stressful? Maybe Tips for Written Exam ncert (maths 11 and 12) + previous papers Tips to fill Application Form if u have any specific achievements.do mention it. Can be sport etc.. and question asked about it in interview. That might add u brownie points Tips for Personal Interview ‚Äì Any other interaction post-interview ‚Äì Full name Bhushan Chaudhari College College of Engineering Pune Specialization B.Tech IT Work Experience (in Months) Experienced (11) Organization(Name) Barcalys Technology Center Designation Business Analyst Work Experience Background Software/IT and ITES Interview Location city Mumbai Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 4 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions No Analytics questions asked Maths/Stats questions 1) Solving system of linear equations using matrices? 3 equations were given i converted them in matrix form then panel asked me whether solution for this system exists then I calculated the determinant of matrix which happened to be not equal to zero hence I answered solution exists and calculated the answer by converting matrix into upper triangular matrix.2) What is rank of matrix and it‚Äôs physical significance? Number of independent rows in matrix . Then panel asked me relation between determinant of matrix and rank to which I answered if the rank is less than dimension of matrix then determinant will be zero and hence corresponding system of linear equation will not have unique solution. Physical significance ‚Äì Amount of information stored in matrix. GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) Yes Is the interview stressful? No Tips for Written Exam class 11-12 Ncert Maths textbooks Tips to fill Application Form I was asked 2-3 questions based on hobby‚Äôs mentioned in form. So fill the form as you want but make sure that you will be able to answer any question if asked on any point you have mentioned in form. Maths/Stats questions What is the probability that the digits of a randomly selected three-digit number will be in ascending order from left to right (without repetitions)? Answer: 0 can‚Äôt be a part of the number. So, there are 9 numbers to choose from. When you have selected three digits out of 9, there are 6 permutations possible, out of which only in 1 will the digits be in ascending order from left to right. So, total number of desired 3-digit numbers = 9C3 Total number of 3-digit numbers = 9*10*10 Probability = (9C3)/900 GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) No Is the interview stressful? No Tips for Written Exam ‚Äì Tips to fill Application Form ‚Äì Personal Interview Introduction to probability and statistics for engineers and scientists Sheldon M Ross (Basic statistics, distribution functions and probability), Basic Linear Algebra (enough material on the web) Any other interaction post-interview Major part of my interview was based on my work-ex and projects done there. Since I did my bachelor‚Äôs in Chemical Engineering one of the panelist asked me few questions on Mass transfer as well. Full name Manasvi G College Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology Specialization B. Tech in ECE (Avionics) Work Experience (in Months) Fresher Organization(Name) ‚Äì Designation ‚Äì Work Experience Background ‚Äì Interview Location city Bangalore Rating interview experience (out of 5 being very good) 5 Relevant Technical/ Analytics/ML questions What is MNF transform? Why did I use MNF transform instead of a simple PCA during satellite image processing? Maths/Stats questions Since I was a fresher from the space science industry, the first interviewer asked me as to why I wanted to shift from space to business analytics. I replied saying that my interest has shifted towards business analytics when I took electives like deep learning and optimization for operations research. I also mentioned that at the same time, my ‚Äòinterest‚Äô and ‚Äògrades‚Äô in electronics subjects were gradually going down. They asked me to model an equation consisting of these two variables, and they also asked me to first answer as to which variable was independent and which was the dependent variable. Initially it took me some time to understand the question during that period I explained as to how these parameters depended on various other factors. Later when I understood their point of view, I answered that interest is an independent variable and grades are a dependent variable as the grades depend on my preparation, my attentiveness in class, etc. The first panelist seemed to be very happy with my response and handed over the baton to the second panelist, who asked me questions about my internship which was based on satellite data analysis. GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) The third panelist asked me questions related to my hobby and was upset to see that I had written just three sentences for the given three blanks. He mentioned that everyone has written very short replies to hobbies. I described all the sentences in detail and they asked me about the different kinds of books I read, followed by questions about my other hobby which was teaching the lesser privileged kids. They asked me questions as to what I taught and which grade of students I taught. That shifted to languages when I mentioned that I sometimes teach in the native mother tongue so as to drive my point home and make the students understand more clearly. My next question was what are the official languages of Andhra Pradesh and then I was asked about languages of Kashmir. I took a wild guess, and also told them it was a guess. Everybody just laughed and a few guesses turned to be right while a few of them were wrong. Is the interview stressful? No Tips for Written Exam Math is the most important section. I think 11th and 12th NCERT math would be the best place to start and brush up basics and later go on to practicing advanced math problems. Data interpretation and logical reasoning are pretty straight forward, and easy to solve. Going through last year question papers would be highly beneficial as a certain trend can be observed in the question paper pattern and one can prepare accordingly. Tips to fill Application Form This is very important, especially for freshers because all the questions in the interview are going to revolve around whatever has been written in the application form. Do not forget to mention any relevant projects since they will add an edge to your profile and the interviewers can ask questions related to those projects as freshers will not have any work experience. Also fill in the hobbies section carefully and thoroughly. Personal Interview I went through the interviews of previous years and made a list of topics to study and go through. But at the end of the day, I‚Äôve been asked questions only based on whatever I have filled in the interview application form. I think its best to be authentic and candid throughout the interview process. Also, one should have a certain clarity as to why they want to pursue this course and how it would be beneficial to them in their future. The panelists are looking for candidates who have a keen interest and passion for business analytics. If they get a feeling that you are genuinely interested and have done your homework in this field, then the chances of converting the interview is very high. Any other interaction post-interview Why business analytics and why not space industry? This has been asked by two panelists. They were probably just surprised, the second panelist realized that I already answered and then he just said congratulations and all the best. What is the integration of mod x? Write the formula and explain Bayes Theorem GK/Current Affairs asked (if any) No Is the interview stressful?
