To help you cope up with your preparation, we have collated the interview experiences of our current batch students. The interviews were mostly based on the profile and background of individual candidates. We hope this would be insightful and all the best! Full name Aseem Raghav College/University Delhi Technological University Specialization B.Tech in Mechanical Engineering Year of Graduation 2017 Work Experience Experienced Organization(Name) Tata Motors Limited Work Experience (in months as on Jan 31, 2020) 25 Designation Territory Sales Manager Work Experience Background Marketing/Advertising LinkedIn URL www.linkedin.com/in/aseem-raghav-a65216160 Tips to fill Application Form Questions can get asked from these sections in the PI round later as well, so be very honest in filling the hobbies, and extra-curricular description section. Tips for Written Exam Attempt previous year PGDBA question papers to get a feel of the exam format and difficulty level. There‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all kind of strategy for the PGDBA exam; you will have to tailor your preparation according to your strengths, weak areas, and the time you can manage to take out for your prep. Cutoff is usually in 100-110 (out of 150) range, but aim to score 130-140 in order to have realistic chances of conversion, as high weightage is given to written score,. Resources for exam preparation DILR ‚Äì Any CAT prep material is sufficient. VARC- Any CAT prep material is sufficient. QA ‚Äì ‚ÄúTest of Mathematics at the 10+2 Level‚Äù book by ISI comes highly recommended. You may also refer class 11-12th Maths books, for revisiting concepts and theory. Pre-interview composite score (Out of 60) 52.33 General profile based questions asked 1. Tell me something about yourself. 2. What are the qualities of a good manager? 3. What is the difference between a manager and a leader? 4. What are your strengths and your weaknesses? 5. Highlight a marketing strategy you used in your domain to your advantage. Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked None Maths/Stats questions asked Q1. What do your parents call you? In how many ways can this name be permuted? Explain this formula intuitively. A: 5! / 2! Q2. What are the types of errors in Hypothesis Testing? A: Type 1 and Type 2 error. Q3. (Gave a problem) What is the type 1 error of this problem? A: Was unable to solve, so told the panelist that i was unable to arrive at an answer, and explained my approach to him. Q4. Let‚Äôs say you want to estimate the number of Red colored Maruti Altos running in your city. How will you approach this problem? A: * The population of my city is approx. 1.8 Cr. * Let‚Äôs say there are 5 members per family. Therefore total families = 1.8Cr / 5 = 36L. * Let‚Äôs say that there is 1 car per 2 families. Therefore total cars = 36L / 2 = 18L. * Maruti Suzuki has a market share of about 50% in Delhi. Therefore total Maruti cars in Delhi = 18L * 50% = 9L * Alto has been one of the best selling cars of Maruti Suzuki. Let‚Äôs say 10% of all maruti sales have been that of Alto. Therefore total Alto cars in Delhi = 9L * 10% = 90,000 * Since Red is not a common color, let‚Äôs say only 2% of the Alto cars sold in delhi were of Red color. Therefore total red colored Maruti Alto in my city ~ 1800 cars. General Knowledge or related questions 1. What does ‚ÄúAatma-Nirbhar Bharat‚Äù mean? 2. What recent government policies do you relate to ‚ÄúAatma-Nirbhar Bharat‚Äù? 3. What policy should government introduce that you think will benefit Tata Motors? Any other kind of questions None Interview duration (in minutes) 30 Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? Maybe Overall Interview Experience 4 Tips for Personal Interview 1. Carefully study the types of questions that converted candidates on this PGDBA WordPress page similar to your own profile have been asked previously in PIs. 2. Your motivation for joining this course will be studied very closely by the 3 panelists. Have a very clear opinion on why you want to join this course in particular. 3. Revise Higher Maths topics, specifically Linear Algebra, Basic Statistics and Probability. 4. For Freshers ‚Äì you may be asked more questions on your grad ‚Äì level subjects, your internship, any project you did, so be better prepared in that domain. For Experienced folks ‚Äì you may be asked more questions related to your workex, and regarding the domain you‚Äôre from, so you may plan your preparation accordingly. 5. Finally ‚Äì no amount of preparation will guarantee that you have an answer to everything asked by the panelists. If you don‚Äôt know the answer, don‚Äôt fret and tell them so rather than beating around the bush. Resources for exam preparation https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLCtUyOrCJbxz-womyB5E_aZhWcLoGDlqA https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLCtUyOrCJbxyRVIqPFaEKENfKO-WXb-AK https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLCtUyOrCJbxznGmIAvFmfwxWhLQ8yHShk https://www.youtube.com/c/Vedantu Pre-interview composite score (Out of 60) General profile based questions asked Q: Introduce yourself A: Well prepared answer Q: Why do you want to leave AstraZeneca and do PGDBA? A: Told how I developed interest in analytics and that I have been following applications of analytics. Q: So you are not interested in doing a management course. A: Explained how I can contribute to an organization using the knowledge gained through this course. Q:Give some examples of the applications which you read recently. A: Explained about the applications of analytics in pharma/healthcare sector. Q:Your interest seem to be more on healthcare. A: Gave some examples of analytics in finance. Q: Why do you think there is more focus on analytics in recent days when these methods were existing from long? A: Huge amount of data generated everyday now and better processing speed. Q: How were decisions made earlier without these techniques? A: Based on intuition and human experience/knowledge and not based on data. Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked No technical questions related to Analytics/ML/DS as I did not have experience in analytics Maths/Stats questions asked Q: Which topics are you comfortable with in Maths? A: Permutations & Combinations, Probability & Random variables Q: What is a Random variable? Give some examples. A: Answered with example. Q: What is a probability distribution? What are the types of distribution that you know? A: Answered. Q: What is Binomial distribution? A: Explained with examples of coin tossing and probability of getting r heads out of n tosses. Q: If you toss the coin repeatedly and want to find the probability of getting first heads, how will you calculate that? A: Answered using Geometric distribution. Q: Do you know about memorylessness property? A: Have read about it, but couldn‚Äôt recollect. Q: Do you know about calculus? A: Yes, 11th 12th level Differential and Integral calculus. Q: Do you know about matrices? A: Yes Q: What is rank of a matrix? What is the significance of it? A: Rank ‚Äì Number of linearly independent rows or columns in a matrix. Denotes the information content in a matrix Q: For a 3 x 2 matrix, what is the maximum rank that it can take? A: 2, Maximum rank = min(m,n) for a m x n matrix Q: How will you calculate rank of a matrix? A: Explained rank calculation using row-echelon form Q: Do you know how to solve system of linear equations using matrices? A: Yes. Explained Q: If you have a 3√ó4 matrix can you find the determinant? Can you solve the linear equations of a 3√ó4 matrix? A: No. It‚Äôs not possible to get a unique solution for a set of 3 equations with 4 variables General Knowledge or related questions No GK questions were asked Any other kind of questions Interview duration (in minutes) 25 minutes Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? No Overall Interview Experience 5 Tips for Personal Interview Go through previous year interview experiences and prepare accordingly. Prepare well for profile-based questions and be clear on why you want to do PGDBA. Avoid mentioning big buzz words like AI, Big Data etc if you do not actually have in depth knowledge of them. Tips for Written Exam I was working in an e-learning start-up at the time of giving the written exam. Before that, I had prepared for the Civil Services exam with Mathematics as my optional subject. So I was fairly conversant with the 12th level mathematics that is tested in the entrance exam. UPSC preparation had also helped expand my vocabulary. Differentiating between correct and seemingly correct English was a subconscious process for me, which helped a lot in the verbal section. So, my preparation before the exam consisted of solving the previous years‚Äô papers and revising some trigonometric identities. Nonetheless, I ended up forgetting those identities in the exam and had to derive them from scratch. Apart from the wisdom to solve the NCERT 11th and 12th maths books, my advice to aspirants is that you should solve all the previous years‚Äô papers diligently on your own even if it takes a lot of time. This way, the solution will be your own and your mind will more easily embrace and remember it. The process will reward you much more than solving any test series. Refer to the internet for detailed solutions only after you have exhausted all your efforts. For those candidates with little background in competitive exams like JEE, GATE, etc., solving a few practice questions of the ISI Tomato exam might be very useful. Try to memorise all the trigonometric identities. Revise all the special cases of permutation and combination and probability problems taught at the 12th level. If you solve past years‚Äô papers, you would realise that most of the difficult questions of the Mathematics part revolve around these topics. The rest are largely basic algebra and geometry questions. Some practice of basic statistics concepts like histograms, pie charts, frequency, central tendency, variance, etc. is also necessary along with the interpretation of graphs. In the verbal section, paragraph-based questions are always very tricky and the most common source of negative marks. So attempt them with caution and practise a lot of such examples. Resources for exam preparation https://www.ctanujit.org/isi-bstat-bmath-exam.html General profile based questions asked No question asked on my general profile Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked No Analytics/ML/DS question asked Maths/Stats questions asked The last panelist (I presume that he was from ISI) asked which topic of statistics was I most comfortable with. I replied in all honesty that I have zero background in statistics, not even at the UG level. Then I told him that I felt strong enough in Calculus and computational methods as far as mathematics is concerned. So, I was tested on the fundamentals of calculus. I was asked to definite continuity, distinguish it from differentiability and then give examples of functions that are continuous but not-differentiable and vice-versa. I was tested on differentiability of some functions posed by the panelist. In the end, he asked me to compute the integral of the greatest integer function from 1 to 10 without using any paper/pen/calculator. All questions were framed as a natural corollary to one another. There was a hint dropped when I was stuck in the middle of a question. There was however not much time given to think before responding. General Knowledge or related questions One panelist asked me questions entirely on global economics. I was asked about Brexit, its impact on India, WTO, special initiatives to promote manufacturing in India by the Govt., economic soundness of the recent decision to raise import duty on a lot of technical goods. There were a lot of questions one after another around the common area spanned by these topics. Any other kind of questions My interview started with the first panelist straight away asking me why does a ship not sink even though it is so large. How does a yacht capsize? What are the types and directions of friction acting on 2 wheels of a bicycle? and so on. All the questions were from concepts involving class 12th level physics. I was found wanting in conceptual clarity in these topics. Interview duration (in minutes) 22 mins Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? No Overall Interview Experience 4 Tips for Personal Interview Practise speaking impromptu in front of the mirror. Improve your articulation. Instantaneous conversion of our thoughts into the most meaningful words is a skill that comes only with experience. Do not mention anything in your form which you cannot defend. Be honest with the panel and do not even think for a second that you can fool them by over-selling yourself. Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Categories Articles Experiences Technical Joka Library to Paris ‚Äì A Data Science Crusade Post author By pgdba_admin Post date September 7, 2016 No Comments on Joka Library to Paris ‚Äì A Data Science Crusade A peek into Team Tabs, one of the three teams representing India at DSG. It was a crisp Friday morning and I was seated comfortably in the plush IIMC library. The PGDBA semester was well underway, assignments were raining thick and fast‚Ä¶life was busy‚Ä¶life was good and I was brimming with excitement. I had only just begun working on a competition, which had started 4 days ago on June 14th 2016. It was an inter-university data-science competition called the Data Science Game . With so many constraints such as limited number of submissions in a day and final selection of only one team from a college, it was, by all means the ‚Äúbig deal‚Äù and a glance at the list of competing universities showed us some tough nuts. There were the usual suspects i.e. Stanford, Cambridge, Oxford et al., supplemented by a host of premier universities from across the world. Certainly our team of four from first-ever batch of PGDBA, though no novices, were far from being among the best in the world‚Ä¶ or were they? And so we ‚Äì Team Tabs ‚Äì prepared a starting output, clicked on the ‚ÄòMake Submission‚Äô button and waited with a muted yet expectation-laced anxiety that any Kaggler worth his salt would be familiar with and then this image popped up on our screen: Most authors describe moments like these with the cliche ‚ÄòThere was a moment of silence followed by‚Ä¶.‚Äô I discovered that they were quite wrong‚Ä¶as my uncontrollable Hagrid-like laughter filled the breadth of the IIM Calcutta library, defiant of the several bemused yet stern glares that were pointed in my direction! Second in the whole world! Irrespective of its ephemerality, irrespective of the pains required to maintain it or the challenges that we were about to face in the coming three weeks ‚Äì it was a moment of reckoning for us, a moment to cherish, a moment to savour. Yet, when I look back I can say with certainty that it was at this point I started believing that international glory wasn‚Äôt beyond our reach. What followed were some of the most gruelling days of my life. Over the next three weeks, we went on to learn and implement Deep Learning (Convolutional Neural Networks) algorithms for image classification. We travelled to multiple universities in a quest for servers to run these algorithms. We learnt, we toiled, we toiled hard and we thrived. When the competition ended, we were the top team from India ‚Äì Yes! Our hard work and perseverance led to us being the Rank 1 Indian team . We were among the 20 teams from around the world selected to travel to Paris for the final phase of the competition and folks, as you read this article, we‚Äôre on the flight journey towards the finals of the competition in Paris, to be held on 9th September. What fills me with even more delight is that not just us, but three teams from India have made it to the final 20 ‚Äì one each from IIM Calcutta-Team Tabs, IIT Kharagpur and ISI Kolkata- The Frequentists (in their ranking order). India has made its presence felt in this 2nd edition of Data Science Game and interestingly enough, all the three institutes are what together constitute PGDBA! It is encouraging to see that three Indian teams have proved themselves worthy of being the global top 20 when 146 teams from 28 countries participated and showed their mettle in this grueling competition. The competition contained an image classification problem. A set of images were given, which had to be classified into four categories. The problem at hand could have been done in various ways. We decided to use deep learning as a lot of interesting work is being done around it and it‚Äôs one of the most advanced techniques currently available. We had a basic knowledge about it and developed more understanding as we moved along. The process of compiling and executing codes went on and we worked hard every single day. The machine learning algorithms take time to execute and with limited computing power at our disposal and time constraint of the competition, we ensured that every iota of it was used. As we were fighting neck to neck with all top notch universities across the world, the task was not at all easy and there were a lot of hurdles on the way. The limited computing power slowed us down. Every iteration of the code required a whole day and thus constrained our capacity to experiment with the algorithm. Soon other teams caught up with us on the leaderboard. To wrinkle out the problems we went to IIT-KGP and ISI to gain server access. However, the terminals at both places were preoccupied. As a last resort, we decided to use Amazon Web Services (AWS). AWS was difficult to set-up because of the complex technicalities and as none of us was acquainted with the process, it made our job all the more difficult. We quickly took charge and read about it from the scratch, spending a precious time of 3 days to figure everything out and get it running. In hindsight, it was worth the effort. Our first run in AWS increased the accuracy by 5 % and it all paid off with the jump on the leaderboard. Now that we look at it, a lot of edge was given to us by our PGDBA curriculum. The basics of machine learning and computing were well laid out throughout the course. It enabled us to deep dive into deep learning and comprehend the technical aspects around it. We also consulted with professors for guidance. With Team Tabs standing at 12 in global rankings, we realize that we have learnt a lot on the way, when we were actually working on the problem statement. We will now be competing with some of the top Kagglers in the finals. The finale would certainly provide us with global exposure as we will get a macroscopic view of what‚Äôs happening around the world in the field of data science by interacting with top-notch data analysts spread across the world. Since it‚Äôs a 2-day competition, the dynamics of the game is bound to change. We haven‚Äôt been able to put in continuous concentrated efforts towards the final round owing to the rigorous academic curriculum this semester and us coping up on classes. We do have a lot to cover but we will keep learning new stuff as we have been doing in the past year. Thus a great opportunity for knowledge transfer and networking lies ahead. With everyone‚Äôs hopes in us, we make our journey to Paris, where the final leg of the competition awaits‚Ä¶ along with our fateful turnout in the 2nd Data Science Game competition. About the team ‚Äì ‚ÄúTeam Tabs‚Äù from IIM Calcutta Pranita Khandelwal ‚Äì She completed her graduation (B.Tech.) in Electrical & Electronics Engineering and Masters in Economics from BITS Pilani. Initial interest in statistics and then further exploration of online courses made her pursue a career in the data science field. Ritwik Moghe ‚Äì He is a Mechanical Engineer from IIT Madras. With no coding background in the beginning, he learnt everything after joining the PGDBA program. Avinash Kumar ‚Äì He is a Mechanical Engineer from NIT Jamshedpur and has worked in manufacturing industry prior to joining the PGDBA program. While in college, he participated in some analytics competitions and enhanced his data science skills after studying in the three institutes of PGDBA. Rachit Tripathi ‚Äì He is a Mechanical Engineer from IIT Kanpur. He has worked on multiple projects in Robotics, programing and data handling areas while he was in college. His keen interest in mathematics and computing drove him to join PGDBA. December 18, 2015 pgdba_admin Campus Life 5 Comments Here comes our atta boy, our cheerful Madhur Modi to speak about our first semester at Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata. He is a CS grad, tinted with the experience of working in Acrobat Team, Adobe, India for 11 months. Let‚Äôs hear what Madhur says! After a not-so long orientation and pre-semester at IIM C, it was time to move to ISI. All of us were already feeling the attachment we had built with each other and formed the spirit of ‚Äòjoka tribe‚Äô within ourselves. We started our journey to learn and started packing‚Ä¶ but we were not done with the pre-semester yet! üôÇ Not before we can have a last photo-session! Even the journey to ISI was an insightful one! Filled with discussions of memories made within the short month. Happy faces! I remember us all at the peak of our enthusiasm when we visited ISI for the first time after the orientation, this time for around 6 months with knowledge imparted from renowned teachers. Since each of us had opted for the hostel facilities, the registration day was spent in lodging and document formalities. It all began with 5 subjects, 8 teachers and 51 students ‚Äì daily two hour classes, twice daily where a moment of flickering attention meant you‚Äôll lose the ability to grasp anything for the rest of the class. Yes! We had teachers who could teach us their subject continuously for two hours and every moment‚Ä¶ each of them they made us wonder how amazing it is to learn in an enjoyable fashion. We all felt so comfortable moving from our 2 dimensional and 3 dimensional minds to nth dimensions and then move down using multidimensional scaling ‚ò∫ ‚ò∫ (was I too technical here? Come to ISI and you‚Äôll know what I mean). I bet all our teachers from ISI would be laughing reading the joke here. By the ways, if you‚Äôre writing about ISI, it won‚Äôt be a just article if you do not mention each teacher separately! Starting from our class teacher and DBMS teacher prof. Pinakpani Pal, it was him who would come to our rescue each time, whether it is to change the mess, requirement of any additional facilities, aid in any procedures or help regarding the subject. He would kindly reach out his hand and solve all our problems in a flick. DBMS was also taught by prof. Amiya and prof. Dilip who would take care of SQL teaching for us. Thanks to him, DBMS was one of the most comfortable subjects in ISI. I still remember the fact that 44 teachers have bhattacharya awards in their name! We all used to marvel at the level of knowledge at ISI, rather, we felt grateful to our teachers for feeding such golden nuggets of information to us daily and Prof. Debasis is the teacher who‚Äôs teaching reminded us the reasons they won those awards. I always felt that he teaches one subject but I learned things anyone would consider is worth much more! From histograms, scatter plots, distributions and tests for distributions, he took us to bivariate and the multivariate analysis followed by more tests and feature selection. Moreover, he took extra classes and doubt sessions every week just to ensure that when we learn, we learn well When you start talking about the teachers, each teacher is better than the other! We had Statistical Probabilistic Analysis taught by two teachers, Prof. Bimal and Prof. Kishan. It was the only subject with no assignments, since probability has such a wide scope. This class was all practical, we were given real life examples and applied concepts to solve them. There was yet another similar subject, inference, taught by Prof. Amitava which encompassed all other subjects and drew inference tests from each of them, filled with more real life examples. We had one more course, or rather, set of course ‚ò∫ Computing in data science taught by Prof. Saurav Sengupta. I could proudly say to those non-cse students who fear how they would learn programming techniques- this is the course that will help you make your first transition. From practically negligible knowledge, this course taught us not just R and Python, but also made us do an entire team project to deep seat the lessons in our hearts. The best thing? We had fun! I would frequently visit the course website and our project blog and proudly say that we have come far, far from where we were when we entered ISI. P.S. do check out the blog of group 1 authored by our group. üôÇ Didn‚Äôt I mention anything else besides studies? How forgetful of me! ISI is a place of happenings! Every other day there were announcements of workshops in various fields of statistics and there were a variety of activities which would now be sweet memories for us with ISI. We flew kites, we had birthday parties, we played games and we had our first formal photoshoot! Looking smart! ISI also had a very special memory‚Ä¶ Diwali! What‚Äôs that? How did we celebrate it? I could boast that it was better than any student had celebrated while at college! Two of our batchmates, Mr. Avinash (a.k.a. Gandhi) and Mukul cleaned their room and turned it into the Pooja venue (see photos in link) We made diyas, did Pooja, sang bhakti songs, distributed Prasad and made rangoli ! We burnt a few crackers and all our rooms illuminated with the auspiciousness on that day! It was one of the best Diwali celebrations of my life! Diwali! Soon after Durga puja, Diwali and Kali puja, we had our final exams and had to say ‚ÄúBye Bye ISI‚Äù I am thankful that our first semester was conducted at ISI where we learnt such a great deal and progressed so far ahead in our skills. It already feels like we can do most of business analytics even though we have ways to go. How could be go away without saying a delightful adios to our Indian Statistical institute? We requested all the teachers to come for a final photoshoot session. Besides one photo present in CDS website , another photo from the last day would mark a fitting ending to our memories and knowledge lending roller coaster ride at the pillar of statistical, mathematical and machine learning institute! Adios! The procedure to apply for admission to the PGDBA batch of 2021-2023 will be available here: https://www.iimcal.ac.in/how-apply We strongly recommend you to go through the admission policy here before applying: https://www.iimcal.ac.in/programs/pgdba/admissions/admission-policy-2021-23-batch 2) What are the topics that are expected to covered in the written test? How do I prepare for the test? Is the test of JEE/CAT/XAT level? The syllabus for a previous written test is mentioned here: https://www.iimcal.ac.in/instruction-syllabus We do not have an official set of study materials recommended for the test. However, you can look through the sample paper here: https://www.isical.ac.in/~pgdba/Documents/SampleQuestion2020.pdf , to assess the difficulty level of the test. The actual paper would be fairly close to this set of questions. The set of topics and the sample paper together should help you prepare for the test. Further, they would help you assess the level of the test, in comparison to other tests. 3) What kind of questions can I expect in the interview? The interview mostly revolves around your basic understanding of statistics, probability and a few other relevant mathematical concepts, your work experience and your motivation to join the program. There may also be questions on other aspects of your profile, some latest events and so on. Here are a few interview experiences of the students from 2020-2022 batch that should give you a fair idea of what to expect: https://aspirants.pgdba.ml/2021/04/03/pgdba-interview-experiences-2020-22/ 4) Is my profile good enough to make it to the program? As long as you fulfill the basic eligibility criteria, your final selection comes down to your profile (including your academics and your work experience), your score in the written test and in the interview, and additionally, the pool of candidates applying with you, given the limited number of seats. 5) What are the expected cut-offs for various categories (General, SC/ST, NC-OBC) for the written test? The institutes do not disclose this information. However, you may know your score in the written test by dropping a mail to the admissions office, post the test. 6) Which of the three institutes awards the degree? The final degree is awarded jointly by all three institutes: IIM Calcutta, IIT Kharagpur and ISI Kolkata. December 18, 2015 pgdba_admin Campus Life 5 Comments Here comes our atta boy, our cheerful Madhur Modi to speak about our first semester at Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata. He is a CS grad, tinted with the experience of working in Acrobat Team, Adobe, India for 11 months. Let‚Äôs hear what Madhur says! After a not-so long orientation and pre-semester at IIM C, it was time to move to ISI. All of us were already feeling the attachment we had built with each other and formed the spirit of ‚Äòjoka tribe‚Äô within ourselves. We started our journey to learn and started packing‚Ä¶ but we were not done with the pre-semester yet! üôÇ Not before we can have a last photo-session! Even the journey to ISI was an insightful one! Filled with discussions of memories made within the short month. Happy faces! I remember us all at the peak of our enthusiasm when we visited ISI for the first time after the orientation, this time for around 6 months with knowledge imparted from renowned teachers. Since each of us had opted for the hostel facilities, the registration day was spent in lodging and document formalities. It all began with 5 subjects, 8 teachers and 51 students ‚Äì daily two hour classes, twice daily where a moment of flickering attention meant you‚Äôll lose the ability to grasp anything for the rest of the class. Yes! We had teachers who could teach us their subject continuously for two hours and every moment‚Ä¶ each of them they made us wonder how amazing it is to learn in an enjoyable fashion. We all felt so comfortable moving from our 2 dimensional and 3 dimensional minds to nth dimensions and then move down using multidimensional scaling ‚ò∫ ‚ò∫ (was I too technical here? Come to ISI and you‚Äôll know what I mean). I bet all our teachers from ISI would be laughing reading the joke here. By the ways, if you‚Äôre writing about ISI, it won‚Äôt be a just article if you do not mention each teacher separately! Starting from our class teacher and DBMS teacher prof. Pinakpani Pal, it was him who would come to our rescue each time, whether it is to change the mess, requirement of any additional facilities, aid in any procedures or help regarding the subject. He would kindly reach out his hand and solve all our problems in a flick. DBMS was also taught by prof. Amiya and prof. Dilip who would take care of SQL teaching for us. Thanks to him, DBMS was one of the most comfortable subjects in ISI. I still remember the fact that 44 teachers have bhattacharya awards in their name! We all used to marvel at the level of knowledge at ISI, rather, we felt grateful to our teachers for feeding such golden nuggets of information to us daily and Prof. Debasis is the teacher who‚Äôs teaching reminded us the reasons they won those awards. I always felt that he teaches one subject but I learned things anyone would consider is worth much more! From histograms, scatter plots, distributions and tests for distributions, he took us to bivariate and the multivariate analysis followed by more tests and feature selection. Moreover, he took extra classes and doubt sessions every week just to ensure that when we learn, we learn well When you start talking about the teachers, each teacher is better than the other! We had Statistical Probabilistic Analysis taught by two teachers, Prof. Bimal and Prof. Kishan. It was the only subject with no assignments, since probability has such a wide scope. This class was all practical, we were given real life examples and applied concepts to solve them. There was yet another similar subject, inference, taught by Prof. Amitava which encompassed all other subjects and drew inference tests from each of them, filled with more real life examples. We had one more course, or rather, set of course ‚ò∫ Computing in data science taught by Prof. Saurav Sengupta. I could proudly say to those non-cse students who fear how they would learn programming techniques- this is the course that will help you make your first transition. From practically negligible knowledge, this course taught us not just R and Python, but also made us do an entire team project to deep seat the lessons in our hearts. The best thing? We had fun! I would frequently visit the course website and our project blog and proudly say that we have come far, far from where we were when we entered ISI. P.S. do check out the blog of group 1 authored by our group. üôÇ Didn‚Äôt I mention anything else besides studies? How forgetful of me! ISI is a place of happenings! Every other day there were announcements of workshops in various fields of statistics and there were a variety of activities which would now be sweet memories for us with ISI. We flew kites, we had birthday parties, we played games and we had our first formal photoshoot! Looking smart! ISI also had a very special memory‚Ä¶ Diwali! What‚Äôs that? How did we celebrate it? I could boast that it was better than any student had celebrated while at college! Two of our batchmates, Mr. Avinash (a.k.a. Gandhi) and Mukul cleaned their room and turned it into the Pooja venue (see photos in link) We made diyas, did Pooja, sang bhakti songs, distributed Prasad and made rangoli ! We burnt a few crackers and all our rooms illuminated with the auspiciousness on that day! It was one of the best Diwali celebrations of my life! Diwali! Soon after Durga puja, Diwali and Kali puja, we had our final exams and had to say ‚ÄúBye Bye ISI‚Äù I am thankful that our first semester was conducted at ISI where we learnt such a great deal and progressed so far ahead in our skills. It already feels like we can do most of business analytics even though we have ways to go. How could be go away without saying a delightful adios to our Indian Statistical institute? We requested all the teachers to come for a final photoshoot session. Besides one photo present in CDS website , another photo from the last day would mark a fitting ending to our memories and knowledge lending roller coaster ride at the pillar of statistical, mathematical and machine learning institute! Adios! What is PGDBA? - PGDBA - IIMC|IITKGP|ISI-K PGDBA ‚Äì IIMC|IITKGP|ISI-K Home About Prospects of PGDBA Curriculum Blog AINA ‚Äì Magazine AINA ‚Äì 1.0 AINA ‚Äì 2.0 AINA ‚Äì 3.0 AINA ‚Äì 4.0 Aspirants Corner What is PGDBA? Feb 1, 2021 ‚Äî by pgdba_admin in Uncategorized PGDBA stands for Post Graduate Diploma in Business Analytics ( PGDBA website ), probably the first two year full time course in India, jointly offered by Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta; Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata and Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur. PGDBA has been started with the philosophy that data is the new oil in this century. With an abundance of data, driving a business successfully and effectively is becoming a tricky aspect. Recent surveys suggest that big data could create $300 billion in value in healthcare alone each year; clever use of location data across industries could capture $600 billion in consumer surplus. Conversely, poor data management can cost up to 35% of a business‚Äôs operating revenue. While the possibility and ability to capture and store the ocean of data has grown up to overwhelming levels, but the right use of techniques to extract ‚Äòinformation‚Äô from these data sets has not been keeping pace with the demands of the industry, and there continues to be a worrying skill shortage across all sectors. More specifically saying, crunching data to generate necessary business insights requires a strong hold on Statistics, Technology and Business simultaneously. The requirement is so rare that the industry hardly sees individuals having the amalgamation of all of these three crucial skills in the domain of Business Analytics. To cater to this need, PGDBA has been built based on three pillars: Math and Statistics, Technology and Business, as clear from the expertise of the parenting institutes. This course offers four semester with an introductory pre-semester. It is true that two years is not adequate enough to generate data scientists and one can hardly scratch the surface of Machine learning and Data mining, but the unique combination of this course gives it a distinct identity which unravels endless opportunities to the participants: Financial analysis, Consultancy, PhD in Machine Learning, R&D, entrepreneurship to build data-driven startups‚Ä¶you name it! V College of Engineering Year of Graduation 2015 Degree and Specialization Mechanical Work Experience Yes If Yes, then total Work Experience in No. of Months 35 Name of the Organization Applied Materials Questions asked in PGDBA interview along with your answers. 1) Which subject are you prepared for? 2) Write 7 independent 5 dimensional vectors? 3) Explain the physical significance of Eigen Values and Eigen Vectors? 4) What are similar matrices? 5) Why are you planning to join this course? 6) What is Ex-Im Bank? 7) What are its functions? Any suggestion for aspirants regarding preparation for written test and interview. Study one of your maths electives well. They might ask you to select a subject and get in depth during the interview. For written test, revise the topics taught in Engineering Maths. Name Saurabh Dubey College Name Delhi Technological University Year of Graduation 2016 Degree and Specialization B-Tech, Mechanical Engineering Work Experience Yes If Yes, then total Work Experience in No. of Months 21 Name of the Organization Greenway Grameen Infratech Questions asked in PGDBA interview along with your answers. Upon being asked which area of mathematics I was comfortable in, I replied linear algebra. The following questions were then asked- Q1) What are eigenvalues and eigenvectors associated with a matrix? Some followup questions about the geometric interpretation of eigenvectors. Q2) What is the cayle Hamilton theorem? Write the characteristic equation of a given matrix. Q3) A fairly straightforward problem on finding the unconstrained minimisation of a cubic equation. Q4) Question on plotting indifference curves of lexicographic preferences. This was followed by a 7-8 minute long discussion on unemployment in India and what factors affect unemployment in a country, with special emphasis on the role of technology. Any suggestion for aspirants regarding preparation for written test and interview. The course and by implication the entrance process expects a fairly strong math background. Be thorough with the basics of linear algebra, unconstrained optimisation and probability theory. It will be of great help in the interview as well as in the course. There were three interviewers on the panel .I was asked to tell me something about myself and what I want to do next (probably an icebreaker). While I was doing that, they read my CV and asked me about my 3-month internship in Taiwan and the work that I did there. Following that up, they asked me about one other project in depth that I did in Physics. (They didn‚Äôt ask me about other projects that were mentioned in the CV which were in relevant fields, like Data structures and another one in Analytics). Then came the part around which majority of the interview revolved. The professor in the middle said ,so you are from IIT Delhi. I should assume you have amazing skills in Mathematics.I said you can say that. The professor sitting on the left asked me about double derivatives, maxima-minima, limits, continuity of 4-5 different functions, each time giving a more complex function and tried to test whether I knew what I was saying and asked me to draw a few functions. But the questions were quite basic and he seemed happy with the answers. *Over to the professor in the middle*. He asked me if my degree had a probability course. I told him that it didn‚Äôt but I did a course in Probability and Stochastic processes for extra credits in third year. He asked me to write the probability density function, the cumulative density function of exponential distribution and then draw both of them. When I did that, he asked me what a memoryless process is. I told him that the future state of the process depends on the current state of the process and not the past states . He said that is not the description of a memoryless process. I tried to make him understand in a few different ways but he said no. Then the professor wrote a differential equation that I had never seen in my life. He asked me what it was. I could only answer that it was a linear homogeneous differential equation because beyond that I had no idea. He said it is a linear homogeneous differential equation but what is the name of the equation. I looked at it and tried to remember but in vain. Then he said, it must have been taught to you in the first year. I said it wasn‚Äôt taught. He said, it is simply impossible. You need to go back home and look at your notes. I couldn‚Äôt argue as it would look bad on my part. *Already sinking in my chair* *Over to the professor on the right* He asked me that you have played basketball on a lot of levels as mentioned in your CV, tell me name of one player. I was relieved that he didn‚Äôt ask the size of the court or the ball which I had mugged up the previous night.I said Kobe Bryant. He asked who is the greatest player of all time. I said Michael Jordan. He asked me to name one player playing in NBA who is from India. I answered Satnam Singh. Then he asked me to name one player from team India to which I answered Amritpal Singh and the interview was then over.The written test had more weightage as inspite of not performing very well in interviews, I was selected. Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Categories Articles General The mission of PGDBA Post author By pgdba_admin Post date January 10, 2020 No Comments on The mission of PGDBA Sticky post By Anurag Malakar, PGDBA Batch-5 (2019-21) The year 2005 | A regular morning in a middle-class Indian‚Äôs life The middle-aged mom heaved a sigh of relief, having just sent off her kids on the school bus. It‚Äôs been a busy morning for her; she had woken up early to cook food for her husband and the two darling-turned-devils of her eyes. She returns upstairs and spends the rest of the morning preparing lunch for her kids who‚Äôll soon be home, arguing with her maid, and reminding the security guard for the umpteenth time to call a plumber to repair the leaky faucet in her kitchen. She watches a repeat of her favorite TV show on Star Plus for a while before going to the market and buying fresh vegetables and bread for the next day. The year 2019 | A technology-enabled morning in an aspirational Indian‚Äôs life The father sits down on the sofa in the living room, exhausted after an early morning run. He checks his Fitbit and grins as the tiny screen highlights that his mean speed was 25% higher than last month‚Äôs average. After freshening up, he wakes up the kids and walks over to the living room. While pouring milk and cereal into three bowls, he observes that the pack of cereals is almost empty. His kids enter the living room and call out to Alexa to play their customized playlist of morning songs, and she dutifully obliges. He whips out his phone, opens WhatsApp and video calls his better half who‚Äôs away on a business meeting. The happy family reunion is interrupted by the sound of the doorbell, which suggests that Amazon will timely deliver the new toy the younger kid had been demanding for the past week. The dad checks the time, gets dressed quickly, and books a cab while tying his shoes. He drops his kids off to school and orders their favorite pack of cereals on Grofers. He calculates that he has just about enough time to finish the Netflix special that he had dozed off while watching last night. The app‚Äôs proprietary algorithm that incessantly analyzes his viewing habit dutifully suggests a new range of TV Shows for him to binge-watch later. The world is generating a diverse range of data like never before. Over the last couple of years, 90% of the total data in the world has been generated. More than 3.7 billion people use the Internet today, and that number is only increasing. Google is processing more than forty thousand searches every second, while 41000 new pictures are being uploaded on Instagram every minute. By the time you‚Äôre done reading this paragraph, Uber riders would‚Äôve taken more than forty-five thousand trips! In this scenario, businesses have an unprecedented opportunity to capitalize on the vast amount of information they are gathering on their current as well as prospective customers. Social Media is analyzing the behavioral patterns of individual users and predicting their affinities with great accuracy. The entire world is moving towards a connected networking platform with the advent of the Internet of Things and Machine Learning techniques. Data has become the new oil, and Data Scientists and Analysts are expected to monetize this oil to the greatest extent possible. But this burgeoning sector is experiencing a shortage of an efficient workforce. The lack of data scientists has become a major constraint, and industries are clamoring for individuals who can make sense of the data they are amassing and provide tangible business advantages. There are a widening demand and supply gap in the market, and five years ago, IIM Calcutta, in conjunction with ISI Kolkata and IIT Kharagpur, had sought to capitalize on the mismatch. That‚Äôs how PGDBA was conceptualized, in accordance to the industry demands while paying due heed to their suggestions. As the fourth batch prepares to venture beyond the gates of Joka, the last one and a half years of training imparted at these stellar institutions are going to be employed. The industry has steep expectations of this bunch of talented individuals. They‚Äôre expected to draw meaningful insights out of data that benefits their businesses. From risk management to healthcare analytics, to behavioral analytics and digital marketing; the needs that PGDBA graduates are expected to cater to are diverse. As the world keeps amassing higher amounts of data, it‚Äôll become increasingly difficult to make sense out of it. It‚Äôll be akin to finding the precisely manufactured red coloured needle out of multiple piles of slightly deformed red coloured needles; surgical precision is critical to ensure it does not become a bloodbath. That‚Äôs where this course comes in, perfectly positioned to meet the business requirements by capitalizing on the technological advancements of the 21st century. Gave a brief explanation on preparing data and common visualizations used like bubble charts etc. What if a categorical variable required had a large proportion of nulls? Post author By pgdba_admin Post date December 3, 2015 2 Comments on What is PGDBA? PGDBA stands for Post Graduate Diploma in Business Analytics ( PGDBA website ), probably the first two year full time course in India, jointly offered by Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta; Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata and Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur. PGDBA has been started with the philosophy that data is the new oil in this century. With an abundance of data, driving a business successfully and effectively is becoming a tricky aspect. Recent surveys suggest that big data could create $300 billion in value in healthcare alone each year; clever use of location data across industries could capture $600 billion in consumer surplus. Conversely, poor data management can cost up to 35% of a business‚Äôs operating revenue. While the possibility and ability to capture and store the ocean of data has grown up to overwhelming levels, but the right use of techniques to extract ‚Äòinformation‚Äô from these data sets has not been keeping pace with the demands of the industry, and there continues to be a worrying skill shortage across all sectors. More specifically saying, crunching data to generate necessary business insights requires a strong hold on Statistics, Technology and Business simultaneously. The requirement is so rare that the industry hardly sees individuals having the amalgamation of all of these three crucial skills in the domain of Business Analytics. To cater to this need, PGDBA has been built based on three pillars: Math and Statistics, Technology and Business, as clear from the expertise of the parenting institutes. This course offers four semester with an introductory pre-semester. It is true that two years is not adequate enough to generate data scientists and one can hardly scratch the surface of Machine learning and Data mining, but the unique combination of this course gives it a distinct identity which unravels endless opportunities to the participants: Financial analysis, Consultancy, PhD in Machine Learning, R&D, entrepreneurship to build data-driven startups‚Ä¶you name it! Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Tag: students Categories General Prospects of PGDBA ‚Äì The Million Dollar Question Post author By pgdba_admin Post date December 4, 2015 14 Comments on Prospects of PGDBA ‚Äì The Million Dollar Question One of the most common questions that we have come across in the past few days is ‚Äì How would placements/internships be? Well, to be very honest, even we don‚Äôt know it. We can just anticipate and hope that it turns out to be better than our expectations. I will share my experience so far, which makes me believe that placements and internships are going to be no less than PGDM (of IIM C) or any other Masters course at any of the three institutes. The companies who are expected to recruit PGDBA students are going to be same bunch of companies who recruit MBA students. There are lots of companies who hire MBAs for analytics role. Now, since PGDBA program aims at bridging this gap, I feel that packages offered would be similar to the ones offered to PGDM students. So far, the companies that hav e interacted with us are Microsoft, SAS, SBI, Deloitte, TCS, IBM, Flipkart, Reliance, American Express, BPCL, Latent View and few other start-ups. (I might be missing out few names). All the companies mentioned here have shown interest in hiring students for internships. Moreover, as per my discussion with the Chairman of this program, there are few other companies which have shown keen interest in hiring students (not disclosing the names, but these are the biggest e-commerce, I-Banks and Consulting firms). It is expected that few of these companies might teach us few courses in the upcoming semesters. Considering the uptake of analytics in companies and PGDBA being the only full-time residential program (of such stature), demand is going to be very high. So, the hopes are very high and I am quite confident that these are going to be met. P.S. ‚Äì All the views expressed on this blog are made by students and have nothing to do with any faculty, college or any official involved in the program. Tags Analytics , PGDBA , placements , students Categories About Us What is PGDBA? Post author By pgdba_admin Post date December 3, 2015 2 Comments on What is PGDBA? PGDBA stands for Post Graduate Diploma in Business Analytics ( PGDBA website ), probably the first two year full time course in India, jointly offered by Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta; Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata and Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur. PGDBA has been started with the philosophy that data is the new oil in this century. With an abundance of data, driving a business successfully and effectively is becoming a tricky aspect. Recent surveys suggest that big data could create $300 billion in value in healthcare alone each year; clever use of location data across industries could capture $600 billion in consumer surplus. Conversely, poor data management can cost up to 35% of a business‚Äôs operating revenue. While the possibility and ability to capture and store the ocean of data has grown up to overwhelming levels, but the right use of techniques to extract ‚Äòinformation‚Äô from these data sets has not been keeping pace with the demands of the industry, and there continues to be a worrying skill shortage across all sectors. More specifically saying, crunching data to generate necessary business insights requires a strong hold on Statistics, Technology and Business simultaneously. The requirement is so rare that the industry hardly sees individuals having the amalgamation of all of these three crucial skills in the domain of Business Analytics. To cater to this need, PGDBA has been built based on three pillars: Math and Statistics, Technology and Business, as clear from the expertise of the parenting institutes. This course offers four semester with an introductory pre-semester. It is true that two years is not adequate enough to generate data scientists and one can hardly scratch the surface of Machine learning and Data mining, but the unique combination of this course gives it a distinct identity which unravels endless opportunities to the participants: Financial analysis, Consultancy, PhD in Machine Learning, R&D, entrepreneurship to build data-driven startups‚Ä¶you name it! There was a panel of 3 interviewers ‚Äì one from each institute. Himanshu Goyal ‚Äì B.Tech. in Production and Industrial Engineering, 2011 , IIT Delhi; 5 years of experience in BFSI, Global Analytics Duration: 20-25 mins Questions that were asked: Tell us about your achievements Why do you want to join PGDBA Write equation for linear and logistic regression (was asked due to my background at work) A puzzle which used the property of mean A question on odds ratio and probability Experience and Review: Why PGDBA? or Why should we take you? needs to be very well prepared. You should be able to show that you are serious about this course and are making an informed choice. Everyone has a reason of their own and you will have to find one for yourself as well which you can pitch. In case you have work experience, you should be able to explain your roles and responsibilities in a comprehensive and confident way. My interview didn‚Äôt go well and I remember not being hopeful after it but my written test had gone very good which must have had a good impact. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Waqar Sarguroh ‚Äì B. Tech. in Chemical Engineering, IIT Roorkee, 2014; 25 months of work experience in Oil and Gas (Refinery) and EdTech Startup Duration: 20 mins Asked to explain the product of the EdTech startup that I worked for. Discussed customer segmentation based on usage of app. Asked to explain classification and clustering and explain the difference. The interviewers were very helpful as I had only an elementary idea about the concept. They walked me through the thought process by asking guiding questions. An algebraic expression of positive integers to be maximised given a constraint. (Using AM > GM) What is BRICS? What is the economic situation of BRICS countries? Did you write CAT? Why not an MBA? SUGGESTIONS-The main focus was on the ability to think through a problem. Building on ideas and communicating your thought process appropriately. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Anushree Parsai ‚Äì B.E. in Electronics and Communication, BITS Hyderabad, 2014; 2 years of work experience at ARM Duration: 30-40 mins As my interview questions were mostly centered around current affairs, I feel the interviewers were looking for students who were good at academics and also kept track of current events of national and international importance. They asked me following questions ‚Äì Which states will be having elections this year? Do you know about GST bill? How will it help? State 3 major achievements of Narendra Modi so far? Factors responsible for Syria conflict and views on it? Based On Work experience: How are defects identified in electronic chips? Define defect and differentiate it from from fault. There was one basic question on mathematics as well on finding continuity of a function. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Naveen Mittal ‚Äì B.Tech. in Computer Science and Engineering, KNIT Sultanpur, 2016 Duration: 20-25 mins Most of the questions related to Computer Science such as complexities of algorithms, sorting, searching, N-P hard problems, etc. Also, questions from management subjects in B.Tech curriculum such as IM, IS, IP were asked. Problems were given which required basic applications of statistics such as mean, median, mode, standard deviation etc. and drawing inferences using such measures. Calculus questions were asked, theorems such as Cauchy-Reimann, etc. were asked. Some HR questions like Why do you want to join PGDBA?? SUGGESTIONS-Be confident. Even if you do not know some of the answers don‚Äôt think that you can bluff with them. Say politely that you cannot recollect or remember the answer. I was able to answer Computer Science and Engineering related questions which happen to be my discipline during B.Tech. and maintain a positive attitude and confidence throughout the interview. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Khushiram Sharma ‚Äì B.Tech. in Mechanical Engineering, IIT(BHU) Varanasi, 2013; 36 months of experience in BPCL as Retail Engineer and Asst. Mgr., Operations. Duration: 25 mins They asked me to briefly explain my profile of work. As I have been to many places during this time and the last one being Gorakhpur (UP), they picked a question from there. They asked me to give five cultural differences between UP & Rajasthan(I am from Ajmer) and also explain how they are different. They stopped me when I had explained four of them convincingly. They asked one question on maths which is as follows : We have identified four places in Rajasthan to be made headquarters of education for state. Out of these we have to finally select only three based on the distances need to be travelled by people in future. All other conditions will remain same for all places. Given this before jumping for any solution, I discussed about further assumptions like population density, shape can be assumed as per my drawing, people will travel to their nearest headquarter (as per straight line distance). Finally they said, all other conditions will remain same for all places. After trying for 2 minutes, they made little bit easier i.e. I have three locations and have to select two of them. Now I drew perpendicular bisectors of this triangle and then explained the solution. They asked me whether I know coding, and I said‚Äù primarily no except that I studied C language 6 years ago.‚Äù Then they asked to write a code for printing my name(string) in reverse order, which I did. I think your approach to the given problem will be a crucial factor in cracking the interview. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Himanshu Jain ‚Äì B.E. in Electronics and Communications Engineering, NSIT Delhi, 2013; 11 months of experience in IT Advisory (Analytics) Consultancy, KPMG; 24 months of experience in Samsung Data Systems (IT industry) Duration: 15-20 mins. P1: starts the interview asking me about my college history and Delhi Current political scenario, what I think about Arvind Kejriwal and what has changed in Delhi since AAP came to power & then asked about some Co-curricular activities. P2(IIT professor of around 40+ age) asked about my work experience as I was working in analytics field Me: I explained about my current client project and what different domains I was working on over the years. P3(one having knowledge of Statistics & maths; must be from ISI): Q1. Given a graph with a normal distribution of mean 30 marks. Also, 20% students have more than 45 marks. So how much % of students have marks ranging from 15 to 45? Q2. Asked to draw a circle and how to find the centre of a circle. I asked some questions in the end about what I can study before joining this course which would help me during PGDBA if I got selected. P2 smiled and replied just chill and enjoy. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Yogesh Dewangan- B.Tech. in Mechanical Engineering, NIT Raipur, 2013; Fresher Duration: 25 mins There were 3 interviewers sitting, 2 males 1 female. Interviewer (I): So Yogesh, tell me something about yourself. Me: Described a little about my background, education, then hobbies and lastly archery (I wanted them to ask on this only ). I: Oh, so you are an archer. Tell us about your achievements in archery. Do you have any certificates related to archery? Me: (showed all national and state championship certificates) I(handed over the file to another interviewer): You can have a good career in archery, then why do you want to do this course? Do you plan to continue it in future? Me: Of course sir, I am very passionate about archery. Our state does not have good facilities and environment for archery. I wish to set-up an archery academy in my state. It will have a great help to the archery community and will also attract new talents. Whatever problems I have faced as a beginner, I do not want the next generation of archers to face them. I: So have you done something in this regard? Me: Yes sir. We have formed a club and para-archery association which helps beginners and needy archers and promotes archery. I personally contribute annually to the club and I like training beginners. I: You seem to be good at maths. Can you solve a few questions. Gave two equation which I don‚Äôt remember, but were of the form x=‚Ä¶ and y=‚Ä¶(quadratic in the form of x) and told me to prove that y is multiple of 9. You have a triangle of sides a, b and c. Tell me the sufficient and necessary conditions for the triangle to exist. Tell me the range and domain for x in: y = 1/(log|x|) I: Can you tell me some headlines on today‚Äôs newspaper? You belong to Chhattisgarh. What are your views about Naxalism. What they want and what you govt is doing to tackle them. Me: Told that they want to run a parallel govt and do not want govt to have any interference in their area. They follow violent route to get their demands fulfilled. Told about the kidnapping of District collector and killing of Congress leaders in 2013. Then told about govt policies and incentives about bringing Naxalites in the mainstream. FEEDBACK: Major criteria for my selection, according to me was my score in the written exam. It played a vital role. Next may be my 10th 12th percentages (both 80+). Then, interview, which I felt went well. I was able to make them ask on archery. I knew Naxalism would come and hence was prepared with it. Everything that was asked to me, I was able to answer. I would say it was totally an expected interview. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Apoorv Agarwal ‚Äì B.Tech. in Mechanical Engineering from NITK Surathkal, 2013; 30 months of experience in HealthCare Insurance, UnitedHealth Group Information Services Pvt. Ltd. Duration: 15-20 mins My interview proceeded as follows: Tell me about yourself (2 minutes) Work Experience (3-5 minutes) Q: What was your work profile? A: I was working as a database analyst in UnitedHealth Group, briefly explained about the project and my role in the company. They were more interested in analytics related work or if we were using any machine learning algorithm. Since we were not using any sophisticated machine learning algorithm at that point of time, I told him how we were doing descriptive analytics in SQL server. Probability/Statistics Questions (2-3 minutes): I was asked to write the probability density function, mean and variance of the Poisson distribution. Real life examples of Poisson and exponential distribution. Bayes Theorem ‚Äì He asked me to state Bayes theorem and its application. Graduation (2 minutes) Interviewer asked me to explain the principle behind swing bowling in cricket(as I did my B.Tech in mechanical engineering and mentioned cricket in my hobbies). I explained it through Bernoulli‚Äôs effect, pressure difference and then there were a couple of questions on Bernoulli‚Äôs theorem. What motivates you to the field of analytics(2-4 minutes): As I was working in the healthcare industry, so I started with the importance of data analytics in the field of healthcare insurance, how we can reduce the overall healthcare cost and serve patients in a better way. I continued my explanation with other sectors and explained how we can leverage data analytics to make effective decisions. They wanted to check my interest in analytics. Extra Curricular Activities: Sachin Tendulkar Vs Virat Kohli- They were interested in statistical analysis behind my answer. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Kapil Tripathi ‚Äì B.Tech. in Electrical Engineering, NIT Allahabad, 2014; 18 months of experience in Manufacturing (Power Function), Trident Group and 5 months in a Project at BHEL Duration: 20 mins. My Complete Interview Experience ‚Äì Tell me something about yourself? Q- (IIM Prof) What is your motivation for joining this programme? I told them about my start-up idea in power sector which deals purely with analytics and how this programme can help me achieve that. Q- (IIT Prof) He said these things shall not be implemented in India. Explained that how government of India has set up 1000 crores for the modernisation of electrical transmission quality and the function delivering those results shall be analytics Q- (ISI Prof) You like electrical ? Can you derive RMS value for a sinusoidal current waveform? Q-(ISI Prof) Given machines downtime periods how the spare parts in your store shall be taken care of ? Any graphs you can plot etc. After some thought, explained about frequency of various spares used in last downtime periods and based on that data we shall generate some bar plots etc. Q-(IIT Prof) Any analytics experience? I told them that I have seen implementation of Aspen tech boiler controller in which learning by controller was done for a month. SUGGESTIONS ‚Äì To be as frank and confident as possible. Decent communication skill and good applied thinking shall be enough for interview. Avoid saying extreme technical terms of which you are not aware of as they will cross question. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Ishita Lohia ‚Äì B.Tech. in Computer Science, College Of Technology, G.B.P.U.A.T., Pantnagar, 2014; 12 months of experience in Tech Mahindra (IT industry) Duration-25 mins. What all tools did I work on ? Why do we use SQL and not Excel for the retrieval of data. Some very basic questions on what our application was and how exactly was I contributing to the organization. Few questions were asked from JAVA and data structures too. What is cumulative frequency? They drew a graph of the cumulative frequency for the number of girls vs marks they scored and did the same for the boys and asked who performed better(girls or boys). They asked me to explain normal distribution and few trailing questions on that. They asked me about different raag as I had participated in singing events. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Palash R Tatte ‚Äì B.Tech. in Production and Industrial engineering, IIT Delhi, 2014; 23 months of experience in Healthcare analytics, IMS Health Duration: 30 mins Questions about my work, grilling me on fine details whenever anything regarding stats or maths was mentioned. Based on previous answer, questions about moving averages when I mentioned forecasting as a part of my work; they tried to dig deep into regression, R square (they asked me to write down its formula) It seemed they were waiting to throw hardcore math questions. But somehow discussion moved on to operations research (but be prepared for math questions, specially when you‚Äôre a fresher) and they asked me to solve a full LP problem. I tried to act smart and solved it graphically for 2 variables which did not go in my favor; they stopped me in between and asked me to do it using SIMPLEX after which I gave up. Who do you think is a better player, Kohli or Tendulkar? They asked about hobbies; on cricket, they asked whether I played any Inter IIT and which ones. They asked about my extra-curricular activities at college. Questions like if not PGDBA, then what? ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì Kallu Chandra Mouli ‚Äì B.Tech. in Electronics and Communications Engineering, NIT Trichy, 2014; 11 months of experience in FCA (Automobile industry) Duration: 30-35 mins Many questions were asked related to work experience. It began with questions like briefly explain a day in your office and questions were followed from what I answered. Few questions were asked about the tools and projects at work. One question was asked about different types of schemas implemented in databases and then types of transformations in Informatica. How would we clean data before entering them into a database . Challenges faced at work . How would you explain a flat file to your grandma. They also asked standard HR questions ‚Äì Why PGDBA. What are your hobbies- I replied cycling and then we had a small discussion regarding cycle prices in India and abroad. There were very basic questions related to normal distributions. I was also asked to solve a question on permutation and combination and then one more from linear equations. Both of them were of CAT standards. I think they were looking for people with interest towards analytics and good understanding of fundamental maths and statistics. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì For the next part of this post: PGDBA 2016-18 Interview Experiences Part-2 Here are the links to the interview experiences of the first batch of PGDBA: PGDBA 2015-17 Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part-1 PGDBA 2015-17 Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 2 Post navigation Next Article Wiser By A Semester Of Statistics Previous Article PGDBA 2016-18 Interview Experiences Part-2 Related Articles Interview Experiences PGDBA 2025-27 Interview Experiences Greetings, Future PGDBA Achievers!
