Mathematics and Statistics related interview questions (if any, please specify in points, else write None) 1. Questions on continuity and differentiability (by IIT Kgp prof ‚Äì I was asked to name a topic I‚Äôm comfortable with) a. Are all continuous functions differentiable? b. Give example of a function which is continuous but not differentiable. c. Differentiate mod(x) ^2 using first principle. d. Few more questions on this topic all of them were basic questions 2. Question on poverty line ‚Äì how, as a policy maker I would distribute funds among few groups of people having different monthly incomes. Given the poverty line of the region, I was asked what would be my approach ‚Äì distribute funds equally among all the groups or implement some other method of distribution. The prof also defined a metric called the Headcount ratio. My answer was to target groups which have income close to the poverty line in order to decrease the headcount ratio but that was a wrong approach as per the prof. The elite Institutes lend their expertise and enrich the course curriculum with Business Data Acumen, Statistics, Machine Learning and Computing, and their contemporary business applications in the Analytics industry. PGDBA‚Äôs unique course structure leverages the industry connect and offers a 6-Month Industry Internship, which provides time to the candidates to prove their mettle in the industry. This has resulted in 70% of the batch securing full time job offers (PPO) with marquee firms like DE Shaw & Co, Mastercard, Amazon, PwC DIAC, Mondelez, McKinsey, and Play Games in the recent years. Over the years, candidates are offered roles in domains like Business Model Analytics, Financial Research, Market Research, Analytics Business Consulting, Deep Learning, Machine Learning, Natural Language Processing, Business Analytics, Risk Analytics, Business Intelligence, Healthcare Analytics, Supply Chain Analytics, Marketing Analytics to name a few. To help you cope up with your preparation, we have collated the interview experiences of our current batch students. The interviews were mostly based on the profile and background of individual candidates. We hope this would be insightful and all the best! Full name Aseem Raghav College/University Delhi Technological University Specialization B.Tech in Mechanical Engineering Year of Graduation 2017 Work Experience Experienced Organization(Name) Tata Motors Limited Work Experience (in months as on Jan 31, 2020) 25 Designation Territory Sales Manager Work Experience Background Marketing/Advertising LinkedIn URL www.linkedin.com/in/aseem-raghav-a65216160 Tips to fill Application Form Questions can get asked from these sections in the PI round later as well, so be very honest in filling the hobbies, and extra-curricular description section. Tips for Written Exam Attempt previous year PGDBA question papers to get a feel of the exam format and difficulty level. There‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all kind of strategy for the PGDBA exam; you will have to tailor your preparation according to your strengths, weak areas, and the time you can manage to take out for your prep. Cutoff is usually in 100-110 (out of 150) range, but aim to score 130-140 in order to have realistic chances of conversion, as high weightage is given to written score,. Resources for exam preparation DILR ‚Äì Any CAT prep material is sufficient. VARC- Any CAT prep material is sufficient. QA ‚Äì ‚ÄúTest of Mathematics at the 10+2 Level‚Äù book by ISI comes highly recommended. You may also refer class 11-12th Maths books, for revisiting concepts and theory. Pre-interview composite score (Out of 60) 52.33 General profile based questions asked 1. Tell me something about yourself. 2. What are the qualities of a good manager? 3. What is the difference between a manager and a leader? 4. What are your strengths and your weaknesses? 5. Highlight a marketing strategy you used in your domain to your advantage. Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked None Maths/Stats questions asked Q1. What do your parents call you? In how many ways can this name be permuted? Explain this formula intuitively. A: 5! / 2! Q2. What are the types of errors in Hypothesis Testing? A: Type 1 and Type 2 error. Q3. (Gave a problem) What is the type 1 error of this problem? A: Was unable to solve, so told the panelist that i was unable to arrive at an answer, and explained my approach to him. Q4. Let‚Äôs say you want to estimate the number of Red colored Maruti Altos running in your city. How will you approach this problem? A: * The population of my city is approx. 1.8 Cr. * Let‚Äôs say there are 5 members per family. Therefore total families = 1.8Cr / 5 = 36L. * Let‚Äôs say that there is 1 car per 2 families. Therefore total cars = 36L / 2 = 18L. * Maruti Suzuki has a market share of about 50% in Delhi. Therefore total Maruti cars in Delhi = 18L * 50% = 9L * Alto has been one of the best selling cars of Maruti Suzuki. Let‚Äôs say 10% of all maruti sales have been that of Alto. Therefore total Alto cars in Delhi = 9L * 10% = 90,000 * Since Red is not a common color, let‚Äôs say only 2% of the Alto cars sold in delhi were of Red color. Therefore total red colored Maruti Alto in my city ~ 1800 cars. General Knowledge or related questions 1. What does ‚ÄúAatma-Nirbhar Bharat‚Äù mean? 2. What recent government policies do you relate to ‚ÄúAatma-Nirbhar Bharat‚Äù? 3. What policy should government introduce that you think will benefit Tata Motors? Any other kind of questions None Interview duration (in minutes) 30 Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? Maybe Overall Interview Experience 4 Tips for Personal Interview 1. Carefully study the types of questions that converted candidates on this PGDBA WordPress page similar to your own profile have been asked previously in PIs. 2. Your motivation for joining this course will be studied very closely by the 3 panelists. Have a very clear opinion on why you want to join this course in particular. 3. Revise Higher Maths topics, specifically Linear Algebra, Basic Statistics and Probability. 4. For Freshers ‚Äì you may be asked more questions on your grad ‚Äì level subjects, your internship, any project you did, so be better prepared in that domain. For Experienced folks ‚Äì you may be asked more questions related to your workex, and regarding the domain you‚Äôre from, so you may plan your preparation accordingly. 5. Finally ‚Äì no amount of preparation will guarantee that you have an answer to everything asked by the panelists. If you don‚Äôt know the answer, don‚Äôt fret and tell them so rather than beating around the bush. Any other interaction post the interview process No Full name Kritica Meena College/University IIT Madras Specialization Engineering Design (Dual Degree) Year of Graduation 2018 Work Experience Experienced Organization(Name) OLA Cabs Work Experience (in months as on Jan 31, 2020) 19 Designation Business Analyst, Associate Program Manager Work Experience Background Analytics LinkedIn URL Tips to fill Application Form Nothing as such, just be honest and be ready with the answers which can be asked based on the details you mention in your application Tips for Written Exam Maths : Solve the past year PGDBA and JEE Mains question papers DILR & VARC: CAT material and mock tests (TIME/IMS) are sufficient for these two sections. DILR will be comparatively easy than CAT exam Resources for exam preparation Pre-interview composite score (Out of 60) General profile based questions asked It didn‚Äôt start with the introduction. I was asked about the WFH situation at my company and then one panelist started asking questions related to my core branch (related to radius of curvature) Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked None Maths/Stats questions asked Was asked to plot the graph of x= tcost, y=tsint for a large range of t (ISI Panelist ) General Knowledge or related questions Panelist 1 from IIM C 1)Cultural difference between Rajasthan and other states 2) Is there any reason why Delhi is more unsafe for women than Mumbai or Chennai? (this question was asked because I‚Äôve lived in different metro cities) Panelist 2 from IIM C 3) Name 5 Rivers flowing into the Bay of Bengal and the longest river of India 4) Current Finance Minister & was Indira Gandhi first female finance minister of India? Any other kind of questions Interview duration (in minutes) 30 Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? Maybe Overall Interview Experience 3 Tips for Personal Interview PGDBA WordPress interview experience page Any other interaction post the interview process Full name Rahul Sharma College/University Delhi Technological University Specialization B.Tech Mechanical Engineering Year of Graduation 2018 Work Experience Experienced Organization(Name) Maruti Suzuki Work Experience (in months as on Jan 31, 2020) 24 Designation Territory Service Manager Work Experience Background Marketing/Advertising;Service and Marketing LinkedIn URL http://linkedin.com/in/rahul-sharma-87b69096 Tips to fill Application Form This is an important step. Aspirant must ensure that they fill the form honestly. Tips for Written Exam Mathematics constitutes 50% of the written examination. So prepare accordingly for it. Make sure you complete all the relevant chapters from NCERT (with examples and miscellaneous exercises). The other major section is the Verbal Section. Try to develop reading habits which will help you ace this section (and will help you in life too). Also try to practice parajumbles and summary type questions. As for LRDI just make sure to go through the basics and you will definitely ace this section. The last and definitely the most important step is mock test. Don‚Äôt skip them. They will complete your preparation. Best of luck. Resources for exam preparation NCERTs + Mocks Pre-interview composite score (Out of 60) 48.3 General profile based questions asked 1. Introduce yourself. 2. Your relevant Work Experiences and acads. 3. Why PGDBA. ( Try to cite relevant work experience ) Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked 1. I was not from an analytics background, so was not asked many questions on this. I was asked about my job description and how data can help better reach the company‚Äôs targets. Maths/Stats questions asked 1. If you are given a matrix 3 x 3. How can you compute 100th power of the matrix and was then asked about the concepts of eigenvectors and eigenvalues. 2. If there are 10 light switches in a dark room then in how many possible ways can you light up the room. 3. Another question on Conditional Probability ( Don‚Äôt remember the exact question but it was something about the reduced sample space ) 4. A basic question on differential Equation. Note: Just prepare stats, probability and matrix and be thorough with all the basics of these topics as these are the most important. General Knowledge or related questions 1. What are the dominant issues in India-China bilateral Relationship. 2. History of this issue ( I started from Nehru‚Äôs forward post policy and built the entire thing as a story of sorts ) 3. What is a possible way forward for India-China relations. 4. What are some recent developments in your district. Any other kind of questions Interview duration (in minutes) Interview lasted for about 30 minutes. Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? No Overall Interview Experience 5 Tips for Personal Interview Just prepare your basics mathematical concepts and try to be well versed with the current affairs. Also don‚Äôt stress over the interview. Just be normal and confident in the interview. Any other interaction post the interview process Full name Rakasi Yashwanth Reddy College/University National Institute of Technology Warangal Specialization B.Tech Chemical Engineering Year of Graduation 2017 Work Experience Experienced Organization(Name) Reliance Industries Limited. Work Experience (in months as on Jan 31, 2020) 27 Designation Shift Engineer Work Experience Background Manufacturing LinkedIn URL www.linkedin.com/in/yashwanth-reddy-rakasi Tips to fill Application Form Fill all details that you can like certificates received in college eventhough they are not high achievements in general. See that whatever you write in application you should be able to explain as they may ask in interview. Tips for Written Exam I read NCERT books selectively based on the syllabus of examination keeping interview in mind emphasizing more on topics like matrices, vectors etc.. As past papers of PGDBA will give a better understanding of the exam we will see that exam is not that tough and we can complete the whole paper within 3 hours duration, try to avoid silly calculation mistakes, this will help as there is weightage of marks of exam for final selection. Resources for exam preparation NCERT books class-11,12 Pre-interview composite score (Out of 60) General profile based questions asked Introduce yourself, Why PGDBA was more emphasized by one panel member as I was from manufacturing background with no prior analytics background. Job role in the previous Organisation, details about products manufactured in our plant and their markets- domestic or international. Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked No technical questions regarding analytics but as I already said I am interested in financial analytics they asked me about crash of stock market in March and recovery, Reasons for recovery FII pumping in money, demand rise, more participation of millenials as the rate at which demat accounts have been opened dailyare very high at that time as valuations looked attractive at that time. How to calculate Valuation Of Companies etc.. Maths/Stats questions asked Highest possible value of n such that 50!/7^n is divisible. Ans: 8 explanation: in 50! Number of multiples of 7‚Äôs are computed i.e 7,14,21‚Ä¶.49 so n= 1+1+1+..+2=8 (2 for 49 as it is square) here generalisation has been asked i.e if 50 is replaced by very large number x, here sum of step values of x/7, x/7^2 ‚Ä¶ till 7^k which is <= x gives the answer. nCr formula has been asked then nCr +nC(r-1) Ans: (n+1)Cr. Relation between nCr and nC(r-1). Ans: nCr=((n+1-r)/r)*(nC(r-1)) General Knowledge or related questions GDP full form and its meaning. Is there any relation of stock market to economy of country. Any other kind of questions They will ask about your Extra-curricular activities and if you have any certificates at national and state level try to highlight them. Interview duration (in minutes) 30 Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? Yes Overall Interview Experience 4 Tips for Personal Interview ‚ÄúTry to be yourself it really helps. If they ask your favourite topic always suggest topic which you are comfortable and related to PGDBA course so that know you are keen to pursue PGDBA. Go through previous interview experiences of candidates of similar profile although questions depends on panel it will help you in knowing general expectations of panel. Be prepared for questions in your current job role and undergrad subjects they may ask. Any other interaction post the interview process https://pgdbablog.wordpress.com/ for interview experiences and try to get in touch with seniors who got selected previously to know their personal experience.‚Äù Full name Aditya Yellamilli College/University Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Petroleum Technology Specialization B Tech Chemical Engineering Year of Graduation 2018 Work Experience Experienced Organization(Name) HMEL, Startup Work Experience (in months as on Jan 31, 2020) 12 (Formal) Designation Process Engineer Work Experience Background Oil and Gas LinkedIn URL https://www.linkedin.com/in/aditya-yellamilli/ Tips to fill Application Form don‚Äôt gas around, no BS, straight to the point answers are appreciated. Tips for Written Exam Prepare well for the math portion, half the exam us math ‚Äî revise from NCERT Textbook and some Fitjee material if needed. There is ample amount of time in the exam so take your time to solve all questions properly. If required take a few mock exams to boost confidence. Avoid mentioning big buzz words like AI, Big Data etc if you do not actually have in depth knowledge of them. Tips for Written Exam I was working in an e-learning start-up at the time of giving the written exam. Before that, I had prepared for the Civil Services exam with Mathematics as my optional subject. So I was fairly conversant with the 12th level mathematics that is tested in the entrance exam. UPSC preparation had also helped expand my vocabulary. Differentiating between correct and seemingly correct English was a subconscious process for me, which helped a lot in the verbal section. So, my preparation before the exam consisted of solving the previous years‚Äô papers and revising some trigonometric identities. Nonetheless, I ended up forgetting those identities in the exam and had to derive them from scratch. Apart from the wisdom to solve the NCERT 11th and 12th maths books, my advice to aspirants is that you should solve all the previous years‚Äô papers diligently on your own even if it takes a lot of time. This way, the solution will be your own and your mind will more easily embrace and remember it. The process will reward you much more than solving any test series. Refer to the internet for detailed solutions only after you have exhausted all your efforts. For those candidates with little background in competitive exams like JEE, GATE, etc., solving a few practice questions of the ISI Tomato exam might be very useful. Try to memorise all the trigonometric identities. Revise all the special cases of permutation and combination and probability problems taught at the 12th level. If you solve past years‚Äô papers, you would realise that most of the difficult questions of the Mathematics part revolve around these topics. The rest are largely basic algebra and geometry questions. Some practice of basic statistics concepts like histograms, pie charts, frequency, central tendency, variance, etc. is also necessary along with the interpretation of graphs. In the verbal section, paragraph-based questions are always very tricky and the most common source of negative marks. So attempt them with caution and practise a lot of such examples. Then I told him that I felt strong enough in Calculus and computational methods as far as mathematics is concerned. So, I was tested on the fundamentals of calculus. I was asked to definite continuity, distinguish it from differentiability and then give examples of functions that are continuous but not-differentiable and vice-versa. I was tested on differentiability of some functions posed by the panelist. In the end, he asked me to compute the integral of the greatest integer function from 1 to 10 without using any paper/pen/calculator. All questions were framed as a natural corollary to one another. There was a hint dropped when I was stuck in the middle of a question. There was however not much time given to think before responding. General Knowledge or related questions One panelist asked me questions entirely on global economics. I was asked about Brexit, its impact on India, WTO, special initiatives to promote manufacturing in India by the Govt., economic soundness of the recent decision to raise import duty on a lot of technical goods. Any other kind of questions My interview started with the first panelist straight away asking me why does a ship not sink even though it is so large. How does a yacht capsize? Maths/Stats questions asked I had mentioned about the course on Probability and Statistics in my UG. The interviewer from ISI asked a lot of questions about Bayes theorem and independent variables. He tried to confuse me on a lot of technical terms and their meanings so as to evaluate if I had just rote them or I really know that stuff. General Knowledge or related questions Conflict in South China Sea. Interview duration (in minutes) 25 Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? Yes Overall Interview Experience 5 Tips for Personal Interview Brush up the basic concepts that you have studied in Class 12th and Graduation. Don‚Äôt try to fool them. Rather accept you don‚Äôt know instead of fooling them around. Get knowledge about application of analytics in the industry you are currently in. Full name Debeshwar Maitra College/University Presidency University, Kolkata (Graduation) & IIT Kharagpur(Masters) Specialization B.Sc(Hons.)+M.Sc. in Physics Year of Graduation 2018 (B.Sc) , 2020 (M.Sc.) Work Experience Fresher Tips to fill Application Form Each and every entry should be absolutely correct. Profile based questions would be based on it. So, be ready to explain all your achievements, successes, failures and choices as mentioned in the form. Tips for Written Exam For Quants I revised Class 11 and 12 Mathematics books. I solved English Comprehension and Data Interpretation-Logical Reasoning questions from CAT papers and the sample paper. Resources for exam preparation NCERT textbooks (for Quants), CAT papers (for English Comprehension and DILR) Pre-interview composite score (Out of 60) General profile based questions asked 1. Introduce Yourself 2. What is your motivation for applying to PGDBA course? 3. Make a Business Case Study on how joining PGDBA would benefit you (Follow up question: What is Opportunity Cost? What is Leverage?) Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked None Maths/Stats questions asked 1. What is the Integral of arctan(x)? Solution: Using Integration by Parts. 2. Suppose you are given the CTC of all students of PGDBA batch. Which measure of Central Tendency would be more important to you- Mean or Median? Ans: Median, since Mean could be impacted by outliers. General Knowledge or related questions What are the provisions of the National Educational Policy (NEP)? Any other kind of questions What is the state of Classical Music artists in India? Why? What role can the government play to improve it? (Vocal Classical is my extra-curricular) Interview duration (in minutes) 25-30 Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? No Overall Interview Experience 3 Tips for Personal Interview Being clear and to the point helps (in my opinion), beating around the bush doesn‚Äôt help. If you don‚Äôt know some answer or if you make some mistakes admit it, don‚Äôt try to bluff the panel. Read newspapers regularly. Brush up graduation topics/extracurriculars/projects and any other thing mentioned in the form before the interview. Full name PILLA RAVI KIRAN College/University NIT Warangal Specialization B.Tech Mechanical Engineering Year of Graduation 2017 Organization(Name) Musigma Work Experience (in months as on Jan 31, 2020) 29 Designation Trainee Decision Scientists Work Experience Background Analytics LinkedIn URL www.linkedin.com/in/ravikiran-pilla-a002a911a Tips to fill Application Form Be Honest, avoid writing anything that you haven‚Äôt done or not comfortable with. Tips for Written Exam Read 11th 12th NCERT Maths, for Verbal, practice RC‚Äôs and Para jumbles from Cat materials. Pre-interview composite score (Out of 60) 55.47 General profile based questions asked Introduce Yourself Technical questions (Analytics/ML/DS) asked Types of statistical problems ‚Äì Descriptive, Inquisitive, Prescriptive, Predictive What is p-value. Define correlation, Explain K-means clustering with examples. all these are formal definitions Maths/Stats questions asked Define rank of a matrix, Linear Independence, Integral as limit sum. General Knowledge or related questions Define GDP, Covid measures taken by central Government. Interview duration (in minutes) 20 minutes Did you feel that your interview was a stress interview? Yes Overall Interview Experience 4 Tips for Personal Interview If you are from analytics background, be sure on the Techniques used. Prepare Linear Algebra and Calculus. Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Tag: Vardy Categories Articles Technical A Record, a Code and Twitter Post author By pgdba_admin Post date January 20, 2016 3 Comments on A Record, a Code and Twitter How my first machine learning model was validated by a goal scored a continent away. Ritwik Moghe It was the twenty-eighth day of November 2015. As the strangely balmy day yawned, stretched and gratefully gave way to dusk, several eyes were glued to the actions of one man. The man was slight, had strange spiky hair and a face that might remind many of all those ‚Äòdawgs‚Äô or ‚Äòdealers‚Äô from Breaking Bad. Only a year back, hardly anyone knew of his existence. And today, he was about to etch his name in the annals of footballing history. As he latched on to a pitch perfect through-ball that split the Manchester United defense in half and slotted it in past the oncoming goalkeeper, several things exploded. One of those was the voice of the legendary Martin Tyler as he shouted ‚ÄúVardy! Its Eleven, it‚Äôs Heaven for Jamie Vardy‚Äù ( The goal as it unfolded ). Jamie Vardy, a name most of you might still be unfamiliar with, had broken the English Premier League Record of scoring goals in most number of consecutive matches. He had scored in each of the past eleven games. In the grand scheme of things, the record, in itself might not be much significance. What mattered more was Vardy‚Äôs story. From an amateur player with no ‚Äòproper‚Äô training or facilities and very humble beginnings, he had risen to be the most prolific striker in one of the most competitive leagues around the world. It was a classic fairy-tale. For several amateurs trudging every evening into those muddy football fields and trying to curl it like Carlos, Vardy was hope. So as he was being engulfed by his team-mates after he had scored that crucial record-breaking goal, Vardy was causing another explosion around the world. It was an explosion of hope, of greetings and of admiration. And sitting in our dorm rooms overlooking the ponderous Barrackpore Trunk Road in the quaint campus of ISI Calcutta, a bunch of us fledgling data-scientists of PGDBA captured this joyous explosion. We captured it using Twitter. A graph encapsulating the positive Twitter sentiment about Vardy right after THE GOAL! The problem that we were working on was Opinion Mining through tweets. Billions of tweets are posted every day. These tweets reflect the opinions or sentiments of the users about various topics. For instance, a tweet like ‚ÄúI love Apple #Iphone6‚Äù might reflect the user‚Äôs positive sentiment about the company Apple. A study of several such tweets about a particular subject or company can provide valuable insights to the company about the general public opinion about themselves. We were analyzing the Twitter sentiment about various current and upcoming football stars. Our aim was to identify the next big star, the one who would eclipse Messi and attain the ultimate pinnacle of fame by someday being the brand ambassador of Tata Motors! Our observation about Vardy and his big day was a mere microcosm of a bigger project where we analyzed over one million tweets about 10 players obtained over a period of one month. The analysis began with mining tweets about the particular players. The tweets were obtained from an API using Python. Relevant meta-data like the location of the user and the time-stamp of the tweet was extracted along with the text of the tweet. The text of the tweet was then converted into a Term-Document Frequency Matrix (TDF). Now only a year ago, all that I could I have thought of on hearing ‚ÄòTerm-Document Frequency Matrix‚Äô would have been Neo in his slick glasses staring into some green numbers floating Chinese-style on an antique nineties monitor! But TDF is way simpler than that. All it does is that it creates a table. Each row is a tweet. All the words observed in all the tweets that we are studying make up the columns. Consider this example for clarity- Thus each word is now a feature and each tweet a data-point. We then used a Machine Learning technique called Maximum Entropy Classifier in R to classify each tweet or data-point into one of the three categories: Positive, Neutral or Negative. (I could get into the details of the work, about why we went for supervised classification approach, about why MaxEnt works best for Text Classification etc. But since I‚Äôm trying to make this article tractable for someone with no prior analytics experience I stop by providing a link to another blog about our detailed work. ( A detailed report of our project ) Now this process was carried out for all the tweets about all the different players. The prevalent sentiment about a particular player was given by the difference between the number of positive and negative tweets (which was also normalized). Doing this helped us observe several interesting trends in the data. Consider the comparative study of sentiments about Neymar, Ronaldo and Harry Kane over November 2015. Also, have a look at how the sentiment about Harry Kane varied across countries. Such analysis has huge potential applications. Imagine how Tottenham Hotspurs, the club which Harry Kane plays for could maximize their profits by opening more ‚ÄòSpurs Stores‚Äô in South Africa where Kane is way more popular (green) as compared to say Australia where he is clearly notorious (red). Are you an executive at EA Sports and want to decide whom to have on the cover of FIFA 16? Just mine sentiment on twitter and viola, you‚Äôll see that Neymar would be a way better choice than Kane. So this was all about our project on Twitter sentiment about football superstars. This project was a part of our course called Computing for Data Sciences at ISI Kolkata. All of our fellow mates from PGDBA have also worked on several such (hopefully: P) interesting projects. Some of them will share their stories with you on this blog as well. Vardy and his record holds a special place in our hearts. He was the perfect muse for demonstrating the effectiveness of our model. When you‚Äôve come up with your first ‚ÄòReal‚Äô model, the true test of the model happens when you see it work in real life on a completely unexpected scale. That meteoric rise in Vardy‚Äôs sentiment at 5.55 pm BST, right after he had scored the crucial goal proved to us beyond doubt that our model worked! So, I sign off with a link to that moment when Vardy smashed a record, the moment when people around the world celebrated the dawn of a new star, and the moment when our model was validated! Cheers! PGDBA is a two year full time residential diploma programme aimed at creating business analytics professionals employable by leading Indian and foreign firms. This programme is designed for those who have an analytical mindset, are interested in tackling challenging business problems, and possess an inclination towards mathematics. Some of the salient features of the programme include courses taught by reputed faculty members at the campuses of three globally renowned institutes, hands- on business analytics training at a related company, continuous interaction with industry leaders throughout the course of the diploma programme, and the availability of placement opportunities at all the three institutes jointly offering this programme. Who is eligible to apply for the PGDBA Exam 2025? A candidate must hold a graduate/post-graduate degree with 10+2+4 or 10+2+5 or 10+2+3+2, with at least 60% marks or CGPA 6.5 on a 10-point scale in the Qualifying Degree (i.e., B.Tech./ B.E./ M.Sc./ M.Com. or equivalent). A one-year MBA will not be considered the equivalent of an M.Sc./ M.Com. Candidates with 10+3 (Engineering diploma) + 3 (lateral entry into B.E./ B.Tech.) with at least 60% marks or CGPA 6.5 on a 10-point scale in the Qualifying Degree (i.e., B.Tech./ B.E.), or with 10+2+4 (B.Sc.) with at least 60% marks or CGPA 6.5 on a 10-point scale in the Qualifying Degree (i.e., B.Sc.), or with qualified CA/CS/ICWA with at least 60% marks (Intermediate and Final examinations of the CA/CS/ICWA considered together) are also eligible. For SC/ ST and Person with Disabilities (PwD) category candidates, the qualifying marks for eligibility shall be 55% or a CGPA of 6.0 on a 10-point scale. The CGPA will not be converted into percentage marks even if the degree-awarding Institute provides marks in the CGPA system. Their admission will be based on the CGPA awarded in the transcript. If the CGPA is on a different scale than 10, the eligibility of a candidate will be based on the equivalence of the CGPA on a 10-point scale. Candidates in their final year are also eligible to apply, provided they appear in the final examination and complete the other academic requirements specified above by Monday, June 30, 2025. In such cases, admission will be provisional, subject to submitting the final mark sheet by Monday, December 1, 2025. Q2. I have completed my bachelor‚Äôs degree. Do I need to submit the overall percentage of marks or as per my university standards? As per the PGDBA 2025 eligibility criteria, you must submit the percentage according to your university norms. Q3. I have not completed my bachelor‚Äôs degree / I am in the final year of bachelor‚Äôs degree. What marks do I need to enter in the Application form? As per the PGDBA 2025 eligibility criteria, you must enter the Aggregate Percentage of the statement of marks (up to the latest exam) provided by your institute. Q4. Is there any age restriction to write the PGDBA Exam 2025? No, there is no age restriction to write the PGDBA Exam 2025. Q5. What is the application fee for the PGDBA Exam 2025? The fee is ‚Çπ1250 for SC, ST and PwD category candidates and ‚Çπ2500 for all other categories of candidates. Q6. How can I pay the application fee for PGDBA Exam 2025? You will be required to pay the application fee for PGDBA Exam 2025 during the online registration through the payment gateway. Use a valid Credit Card, Debit Card, Net Banking, UPI or Wallet facility. Q7. When and how do I register for PGDBA Exam 2025? You can apply from 14-Feb-25 to 06-Mar-25. Please visit the IIM-C PGDBA 2025 website, followed by the Application Form. Q8. From where can I get the list of exam cities? A list of exam cities will be available on the IIM-C PGDBA 2025 website before the start of registration. Q9. When will I get my Admit Card? Please visit the IIM-C PGDBA 2025 website regularly to get the latest updates. Q10. Will the Admit Card be sent to me as a hard copy or by mail? No. You must download it from the respective link given on the IIM-C PGDBA 2025 website. Q11. Are there any special provisions for Person with Disability candidates? Yes, there are special provisions for PwD candidates. Please refer to the FAQs for PwD candidates for more details. Q12. What are the time slots for the PGDBA Exam 2025? Please visit the IIM-C PGDBA 2025 website regularly to get the latest updates. Q13. I made a mistake(s) during registration for the PGDBA Exam 2025 and have created my user ID and password. What should I do now? You cannot edit personal details (Date of birth, email address, mobile number etc.) entered during registration once you confirm the submission. If you have made a mistake in these details, you must register again with a new email ID. Your application will be considered for the latest registration and the Admit Card will be issued for the same. Please note that you will not receive a refund or Admit Card for your earlier registration. Failure to re-register in such circumstances may lead to nullification of your candidature. It is recommended to preview your application form before submission to ensure all the details are correct. Q14. What are the times to contact the PGDBA Admissions Helpdesk 2025? For external queries related to PGDBA Admissions 2025, please call (+91) 33-7121-1203/1204 between 9:30 AM to 5:30 PM on Monday to Friday and/or drop your email on pgdbaadmissions@iimcal.ac.in . For queries related to the PGDBA Application Portal, please call (+91) 22-6130-6267 between 9:00 AM to 6:00 PM from Monday to Saturday and/or drop your email on pgdbahelpdesk.2025@iimcal.ac.in Q15. If I do not get my Admit Card, whom should I contact? The Admit Card needs to be directly printed from the IIM-C PGDBA 2025 website using your User ID and Password. If you are unable to view your Admit Card after logging in, please contact: Toll No: 022-61306267 Email: pgdbahelpdesk.2025@iimcal.ac.in Q16. In case the website does not work, and I am unable to complete my application, what should I do? If the registration website is not accessible for any reason, please close your Internet browser and try again. Ensure you have having stable internet connection. The Registration/Application form is best viewed in Mozilla Firefox and Google Chrome browsers. Please Contact the PGDBA 2025 Helpdesk for more instructions: Toll No: 022-61306267 Email: pgdbahelpdesk.2025@iimcal.ac.in Q17. I have completed 5-year dual degree course (BTech + MTech, BS+MS, BTech + MSc etc.). How do I enter my marks for a bachelor‚Äôs degree? As per your University norms, you must enter the aggregate of marks that are equivalent to a bachelor‚Äôs degree under the bachelor‚Äôs degree section and the equivalent marks for the Master‚Äôs degree under the Master‚Äôs degree section. Q18. A) I have an SC/ST certificate in the format uploaded on the IIM-C PGDBA 2025 website. Can I use the same certificate, or do I have to download the certificate template from the IIM-C PGDBA website and fill it out again? If your certificate fulfils the following conditions, you can upload the same certificate: The certificate should have been issued by a competent authority on or after 1st April, 2024 The name of the caste and caste number should appear on the certificate. The Ministry's resolution/order number should be available. The certificate should be in Hindi or English only. The authorities competent to issue the certificate are: District Magistrate /Additional District Magistrate /Collector /Deputy Commissioner /Additional Deputy Commissioner / Deputy Collector / I Class Stipendiary Magistrate /City Magistrate /Taluka Magistrate /Executive Magistrate / Extra Assistant Commissioner /Chief Presidency Magistrate / Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate /President Magistrate /Revenue Officers not below the rank of Tahsildar /Sub Divisional Officer of the area where the person and his family normally resides /Development Officer. Note: The certifying authority should be the one concerned with the locality in which the person applying for a certificate has his permanent place of abode. Revenue Authorities have been empowered to issue certificates based on a certificate issued by an MP, MLA, Gazetted Officer, etc. But they should do so only after proper verification and after having satisfied themselves with the corrections. Q18. B) Is there validity for the NC-OBC Certificate? Refer to the Government of India Department of Personnel & Training office memorandum on the validity period of the NC-OBC Certificate. https://www.ncbc.nic.in/Writereaddata/36036_2_2013-Estt-Res_30052014635430196013010641.pdf Q18. C) Which authority issues the NC-OBC certificate? Refer to the Government of India website www.ncbc.nic.in ( http://www.ncbc.nic.in ) for details. List of Authorities empowered to issue caste/community certificates http://documents.doptcirculars.nic.in/D2/D02adm/36028_1_2014-Estt.Res.-03092015A.pdf How to reach: Click on www.ncbc.nic.in ->Related Links -> Department of Personnel & Training --> http://persmin.gov.in -> Department of Personnel & Training (DOPT) - > Notifications > OMs & Orders -> 12. Estt (Reservation) ->12.2 Brochure on Reservation For SC, ST and Other Backward Classes in Services (PART-I) -> Others -> S. No. 30 Q19. I have changed my name with due procedure after completing my degree. Should I enter my name as per the degree certificate or the changed name? You must enter your changed name and provide the supporting documents for change of name at the time of examination, interview and admission. Q20. What should I do if I have not received the password or have lost the SMS? If you have not received the password or have lost the SMS, click the Forgot User ID/Password option on the Existing User login page. You will be prompted to enter your registered Email ID and a Captcha string. The new password will be sent to your registered email address. Note: Regenerated passwords will not be sent as an SMS. Q21. What should I do if I am not able to locate the user ID? Please click on the Forgot User ID/Password button on the Existing User login page enter your registered Email ID and prompt Captcha string to receive the User ID/Password on the registered Email ID. Q22. I have received multiple passwords. Which password I should enter to log in? You need to use the password contained in the most recent SMS you have received. In case you are not able to login, you can simply use your user id and click ‚Äòforgot password‚Äô. You will receive a new password through email on your registered email id. Q23. University name is not mentioned in the drop-down list while filling the application form? If your university‚Äôs name does not appear in the drop down, you may select the option ‚ÄúOthers‚Äù from the drop down list. Write your university/institute name in the ‚ÄúOther University/Institute Name:‚Äù text box. < Back Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Instagram Connect With Us For all queries related to Academic Curriculum of PGDBA Programme offered at IIM Calcutta: PGDBA Programme Office, IIM Calcutta: Phone: (+91) 33-7121-1201/1202 [Mon-Fri, 9:30 hrs. ‚Äì 17:30 hrs.] Email: pgdba@iimcal.ac.in Quick Links Announcement Feedback Jobs@IIMC Life@IIMC Library Media Room Tenders Useful Links Pay Online Centers of Excellence Contacts Annual Reports CPPP NIRF Site Map 360¬∞ Virtual Tour Institute Gift Shop Policies RTI IIM Act IIM Rules IIMC Regulations Equal Opportunities Anti-Sexual Harassment Privacy Terms of Use English ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä A+ A A- Screen Reader Dark Mode label ¬© 1961-2026 Indian Institute of Management Calcutta

Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Categories Articles Technical Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge Post author By pgdba_admin Post date January 31, 2016 1 Comment on Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A brief overview on how I approached a real world healthcare problem via Analytics. Robin Singh Disclaimer : I have tried to restrict technicalities to a minimum in the blog, so as to cater to a wider segment of readers. However, a little awareness about machine learning will make the rest of the post even more comprehensible and hopefully exciting. The healthcare industry is not only huge but also has a tremendous potential for the use of technology and data science. In this post, I will share one of the numerous instances of the use of unconventional analytics to engineer solutions in response to challenges in the field of healthcare. This seemingly complex idea, can be structured and implemented by a combination of machine learning tools and data crunching techniques. The solution proposed here is designed to work with critical patient data in hospitals and raise an alarm when the state of the patient degrades, eventually leading to potentially fatal outcomes. Now the obvious questions, How will such a system help? Can the doctors not monitor patient state physically? Well, it is only possible for a doctor to physically monitor a small number of patients. What if the number of patients is large?. Also, the decision to provide intensive care to patient after an alarm has been raised has monetary and human life impacts. If the alarm can be raised in time, intensive care although expensive, can be provided to the patient. At the backend, the model can be seen as a typical classification machine learning problem . Classification, as the name suggests is a method to categorize data points into predetermined target groups. Numerous algorithms can do classification like Bayesian model, decision tree, random forest, regression etc. We used Random Forest model for the current data set, due to simplicity and ease of implementation. However, the classification method happened to be only the tip of the iceberg. There were many unforeseen challenges ‚Äì primarily due to data coming from the healthcare domain and also computational resource constraints. First, healthcare data is highly erratic and the severity of a measurement varies from person to person. For example, a certain value of a respiratory measurement can be dangerous and life risking for a normal person but normal for a smoker. This poses a fundamental challenge to the accuracy of models built on the healthcare data. Second, the state to be predicted is different from the state whose training data is available. This is slightly difficult to grasp, but lets try. We want to raise an alarm when the patient‚Äôs situation is worsening from normal and approaching mortality but still the patient has time. However, the training dataset has information on the actual mortality/no-mortality. Using the training data to learn will imply making an approximation. The third challenge comes from implementation aspects. The prediction of no-mortality should be highly reliable as compared to prediction of mortality. The system should be able to predict the no-mortality situations with an accuracy of 99% or above. Accuracy in no-mortality and mortality have a trade-off and hence if we tune the model for high accuracy in no-mortality then the accuracy on mortality is low. Let‚Äôs take a moment to think about the methodology again. What can we observe? The predictive model seems to be replicating logic similar to a real doctor. In fact, the very idea of machine learning is to train the machines to apply logic like human beings do. For example, using the past data to learn and take decisions in the future cases, considering trade-offs originating from the decision making process and using the concept of information value to take decision. Discussed above is one example on the use of analytics and artificial intelligence in the healthcare scenario. There are many unexplored applications in the domain, a huge scope for improvement in the existing models and unquantifiable amount of data to process. In the coming years devices based on such models will be a reality and the industry requires many more analyst to cater to the demand. Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Categories General Prospects of PGDBA ‚Äì The Million Dollar Question Post author By pgdba_admin Post date December 4, 2015 14 Comments on Prospects of PGDBA ‚Äì The Million Dollar Question One of the most common questions that we have come across in the past few days is ‚Äì How would placements/internships be? Well, to be very honest, even we don‚Äôt know it. We can just anticipate and hope that it turns out to be better than our expectations. I will share my experience so far, which makes me believe that placements and internships are going to be no less than PGDM (of IIM C) or any other Masters course at any of the three institutes. The companies who are expected to recruit PGDBA students are going to be same bunch of companies who recruit MBA students. There are lots of companies who hire MBAs for analytics role. Now, since PGDBA program aims at bridging this gap, I feel that packages offered would be similar to the ones offered to PGDM students. So far, the companies that hav e interacted with us are Microsoft, SAS, SBI, Deloitte, TCS, IBM, Flipkart, Reliance, American Express, BPCL, Latent View and few other start-ups. (I might be missing out few names). All the companies mentioned here have shown interest in hiring students for internships. Moreover, as per my discussion with the Chairman of this program, there are few other companies which have shown keen interest in hiring students (not disclosing the names, but these are the biggest e-commerce, I-Banks and Consulting firms). It is expected that few of these companies might teach us few courses in the upcoming semesters. Considering the uptake of analytics in companies and PGDBA being the only full-time residential program (of such stature), demand is going to be very high. So, the hopes are very high and I am quite confident that these are going to be met. P.S. ‚Äì All the views expressed on this blog are made by students and have nothing to do with any faculty, college or any official involved in the program. Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Categories Articles Experiences ISI Chapter Chances of Consequence Post author By pgdba_admin Post date September 20, 2016 No Comments on Chances of Consequence Grown-ups love figures. When you tell them that you‚Äôve made a new friend, they never ask you any questions about essential matters. They never say to you, ‚ÄúWhat does his voice sound like? What games does he love best? Does he collect butterflies?‚Äù Instead, they demand: ‚ÄúHow old is he? How many brothers has he? How much does he weigh? How much money does his father make?‚Äù Only from these figures do they think they have learned anything about him. -The Little Prince Our first exams in this first semester at ISI have finally arrived. One of the subjects of the course, and of the more interesting ones I might add, is ‚ÄòProbability and Stochastic Processes‚Äô. This was also the subject of our first exam. I have been pouring over notes and hundreds of pages of text in preparation of this exam. The intricacies in some of the ideas reminded me of these lines taken from ‚ÄòThe Little Prince‚Äô and quoted by David Freedman in his book on Statistics. Are such matters as figures and charts always dry and boring? In our first class, the professor of the same subject also remarked, ‚ÄúMaybe our insistence on numbers is the limitation of man‚Äù. ‚ÄòThe Little Prince‚Äô is a famous classic written by Saint Antoine du Exupery. Although it was first written as a children‚Äôs book, it has been enjoyed over the years by adults alike as a heart-warming story on friendship, growing-up and the curious fascinations of man. One of the oft used coinages in the book is the phrase ‚Äòmatters of consequence‚Äô. The Little Prince finds, at one point, a man aimlessly counting stars to the extent that he reaches ‚Äòfive hundred and one million‚Äô. This man then ironically refers to his counting as a matter of consequence. In these days leading up to our exams, I began to wonder whether factuality could be made interesting in the context of some intricacies I came across in problems of Probability Theory. Are there questions that I can ask that are not as dry as the character‚Äôs occupation of counting in The Little Prince? Consider the following questions. How many random people would I need to collect in a room, such that there would be half a chance that at least two of them share their birthdays? The answer to this is a surprisingly low number. Let‚Äôs look at a different question. How many people would I need to catch hold of and ask birthdays of to have half a chance of finding someone who shares my birthday? It is also interesting to note that this number is different from the first one. Louis CK, the famous stand-up comedian, made an interesting remark in one of his live shows. He said that there were enough people attending his show for there to be a fair chance that a few of them would die in the coming year. Ouch! Let‚Äôs pose that as a question on chance. Assume a population with a certain death rate. What is the number of people I would have to randomly collect in a room, such that there would be half a chance that someone would die tomorrow? Enough with birthdays and death days. Consider coin tosses. Say, I keep tossing a coin and keep getting heads for a hundred tosses. I only know that it is equally likely that my coin is anything between a perfectly rigged coin to a perfectly fair coin. What is the chance that I win if I bet on the next toss to be heads? Let‚Äôs stretch this slightly further. Let us assume that when the universe was born, the probability that the sun would rise over planet earth each day was made to depend on a coin toss. We only know that this coin was likely to be anything between a perfectly fair to a perfectly unfair coin (God is playing a cruel game). What is the probability that the sun would rise tomorrow, given that it has been rising each day over all these years since the birth of the universe? Let‚Äôs give some rest to our poor coin and move on to other questions. The Monty Hall Problem is a famous example on how sometimes the idea of chance can stump intuition. Here‚Äôs a different example in a similar vein. Suppose there are three suspects in jail who have been cleared of any wrongdoing and are all going to be released soon. It is announced that two of the three would be released the next day but these three don‚Äôt know exactly which two of them will be released. One of them decides to go ask the guard which one of the other two prisoners is going to be released. But then he thinks the following to himself, ‚ÄúAfter I have asked, I have only a one in two chance that I‚Äôm the second guy to be released. But before I ask, there is a two in three chance that I will be one of the guys to be released. So should I rather not ask?‚Äù Like one of our professors quips so often, ‚ÄòRemember that there‚Äôs a chance model somewhere in the background.‚Äô Somebody somewhere is flipping a coin. Maybe someday a story will be written on a travelling mathematician who visits magical planets to ask questions on chances of consequence. It‚Äôs a long shot that it would be anything as beautiful as the masterpiece that is the ‚ÄòThe Little Prince‚Äô. But I wager it wouldn‚Äôt be as bad as dry pointless counting. ‚Üê Joka Library to Paris ‚Äì A Data Science Crusade ‚Üí Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Leave a Reply Cancel reply Your email address will not be published. The elite Institutes lend their expertise and enrich the course curriculum with Business Data Acumen, Statistics, Machine Learning and Computing, and their contemporary business applications in the Analytics industry. PGDBA‚Äôs unique course structure leverages the industry connect and offers a 6-Month Industry Internship, which provides time to the candidates to prove their mettle in the industry. This has resulted in 70% of the batch securing full time job offers (PPO) with marquee firms like DE Shaw & Co, Mastercard, Amazon, PwC DIAC, Mondelez, McKinsey, and Play Games in the recent years. Over the years, candidates are offered roles in domains like Business Model Analytics, Financial Research, Market Research, Analytics Business Consulting, Deep Learning, Machine Learning, Natural Language Processing, Business Analytics, Risk Analytics, Business Intelligence, Healthcare Analytics, Supply Chain Analytics, Marketing Analytics to name a few. The Prologue ‚Äì 30 days at Joka The Tales of the Triumvirate Interview Experiences PGDBA 2025-27 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2024-26 Interview experiences PGDBA 2023-25 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2022-24 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2021-23 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2020-22 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2019-21 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2018-20 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2017-19 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2016-18 Interview Experiences Part-1 PGDBA 2016-18 Interview Experiences Part-2 Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA PGDBA 2015-17 Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 2 PGDBA 2015-17 Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 1 PGDBATalks AINA ‚Äì Magazine AINA ‚Äì 1.0 AINA ‚Äì 2.0 AINA ‚Äì 3.0 AINA ‚Äì 4.0 Resources FAQs Tweet Share Pin it PGDBA Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 1 February 22, 2016 pgdba_admin General , Interview Experiences 3 Comments Madhur Modi takes up the onus of compiling interview experiences of students currently enrolled in PGDBA 2015-17 batch. The aim is to provide a general idea about the profile of the students and their respective interview experiences to help aspirants prepare better for the big day. PS ‚Äì The interview panel consisted of three members. Bharathi Ramaraj ‚Äì B.Tech in Electronics and Telecommunications Engineering; International Chess Player ‚ÄúI introduced myself as a chess player. And the first thing that followed was why I wanted to pursue Analytics, being a chess player. I said, I wanted to make an impact, also decision making plays a big role in analytics thus being a chess player gives me the apt mindset in the field. I gave real-life examples where I used chess playing skills and also highlighted my enthusiasm towards chess by describing how I view situations as a chessboard and how I involve members as pieces playing the game. The panelists gave me new situations to test my viewpoint by letting me turn the interview into a game of chess where the panelists and I were pieces on the board. I took up the problem and described various strategies that I had at my disposal. I spoke at length about the best strategy that I would deploy to win the game. They also asked about the factors which led me to pursue analytics like my placement in an analytics company and why I wanted to complete postgraduate studies. To this I replied, doing it now would help me save time and gain an early advantage which will be very valuable in the long run. My interview was relatively short compared to other candidates.‚Äù ****** Shashank Kumar -B.Tech in EEE , 2.5+ years of experience in VLSI design ‚ÄúI was the first person to be interviewed at my center. The conversation started with current affairs and the morning news. The analytics projects during my engineering were heavily focused upon. Technical questions included topics like probability, regression, various types of regression and analysis of the quality of fit based on residual plots. The interview spanned around 15 minutes. In hindsight, I think it was a pretty short interview‚Äù ****** Sajal Jain ‚Äì Class representative (PGDBA 2015-2017),B.Tech in Civil Engineering with 4 years of experience in software industry ‚ÄúMy interview wasn‚Äôt strictly a technical one. The few questions included questions on differentiability and continuity and other basic mathematical concepts. My interview majorly focused on how, in my view, my background of civil engineer with more than 4 years of experience in software industry would indulge in a career in analytics and add a different value and perspectives to the batch. The questions were not at all tough so I would advise the candidates to be firm in their basics‚Äù ****** Ayan Sengupta , a fresher who has done BSc and MSc in mathematics and computing ‚ÄúHaving a background different from most of the other candidates, my interview was naturally quite unique in its own way. I expected a tough line of questioning from the panelists but my interview consisted of aptitude questions such as how I would find a method for the CEO of the company I work in to cross a river given that he doesn‚Äôt know swimming. There were also other puzzles such as ‚Äì Why manholes are round and simple mathematical questions covering number theory . The interview was around 20-25 minutes long.‚Äù ****** Shoorvir Gupta , a fresher in mechanical engineering and an IES aspirant ‚ÄúMy interview started with the description of my college and grades. I mentioned my college life and how I became inclined towards gaming, had all A‚Äôs in technical subjects, very high CAT score and a 10 pointer in internship. The rest of the interview was focused on IES and related questions to various fields in IES, questions on strength of material and on boilers and its parts (mechanical subjects). Technical questions were mostly around probability and statistics and its applications. Towards the end of the interview they also asked about my background and hometown related questions.‚Äù ****** Ritwik Prashant , a fresher with B.Tech in Mechanical Engineering and amongst the most meticulous students within the batch ‚ÄúI started with my introduction and how I was in touch with analytics (Coursera courses). I also described my interests in fantasy football where one has to apply optimizations and statistics in decision making. Technical questions were based around matrices where they made a deep dive until they touched unfamiliar topics. Being a fresher from IIT Madras, they also questioned me about my college placement and my orientation towards this course rather than taking up a job. Thus my entire interview was based on the initial steer I had provided with my introduction.‚Äù ****** Pranita Khandelwal , a fresher with dual degree (EEE and Economics) ‚ÄúThe interview started off with the recurring question about my degrees- how I ended up studying both Economics and EEE. Later, I was tested on my knowledge of econometrics, and the panel asked some conceptual questions on linear regression and decision making using hypothesis testing. This was followed by questions related to my projects and internships .‚Äù ****** Avinash Kumar, a mechanical engineer with 2.5 years of manufacturing experience ‚ÄúI steered my interview with my introduction towards my college project at USA and my job profile description. The questions covered as to how I could apply data analytics to these projects and how other projects such as six sigma projects are related to analytics. Among technical questions, most of them were based on geometry and also tested my creativity and open mindedness. I had applied through GATE and was oriented towards aerodynamics so I mentioned why I wanted to pursue an analytics career and implement analytics in aerodynamics sector. I highlighted my orientation with awards (NASA system engineering award-1st prize) and description of college project. Even though most of the other candidates had 15 minute interviews that day, mine was a lengthy 35 minute one.‚Äù ****** Mukul Kumar , a mechanical engineer with 2.5 years of manufacturing experience and with same background as Avinash Kumar ‚ÄúJust like Avinash, I steered my interview with my introduction towards why I wanted to pursue analytics. I mentioned how I had researched and gained opinion about analytics from my peers and seniors and felt that the course aligns with my interests in mathematics and thus I can do justice to the course. Technical questions included mathematical ones (hyperbolic functions and their graphs, differentiation,1st differentiation principle and limit) but none on mechanical engineering. I had also applied through GATE and was asked the interview calls I had received. There were also questions based on puzzles and a few questions from written test which we had given during the pre-interview process.‚Äù ****** Sujan Biswas ‚Äì BSc and MSc in chemistry, 2.75 years of experience in Banking and financial services ‚ÄúMy panelists began with questions about my background and current job profile and drifted over to mathematical questions covering even and odd functions and matrices. Other questions included optimization based questions and decision making problems such as the methods and parameters one would use to determine whether to provide a loan to an individual or not. There were also situational problems such as ‚Äì Given that Ph.D students have a higher default rate but high profits and MBA students have lower default rate and lower profits, how would you define your business. Overall my interview was nice and the panelists were not grilling.‚Äù ****** Mohammed Tariq , B.Tech in computer science in engineering, 10 months of experience in Business intelligence ‚ÄúPrior to joining the course, I described my experience of a 6-month certification course in analytics. I was also asked about statistics. They asked in-depth questions on calculus going to the levels at which I could not solve. Since I have already done a PG course which used R programming language, Tableau tool and projects, I answered what subjects I learned during the course, experience of the course and my development of interest in PGDBA after completing the course. The interview was mainly focused on my interests in analytics.‚Äù Analytics Experience IIM Calcutta Interview PGDBA Student Life students Post navigation Next Article Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge Previous Article PGDBA Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 2 Related Articles Interview Experiences PGDBA 2025-27 Interview Experiences Greetings, Future PGDBA Achievers! Analytics in Healthcare ‚Äì Xerox Challenge A Record, a Code and Twitter FINTECH Hackathon by NPCI at IIMC Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA Chances of Consequence Tag: IIM Calcutta Categories Articles General The mission of PGDBA Post author By pgdba_admin Post date January 10, 2020 No Comments on The mission of PGDBA Sticky post By Anurag Malakar, PGDBA Batch-5 (2019-21) The year 2005 | A regular morning in a middle-class Indian‚Äôs life The middle-aged mom heaved a sigh of relief, having just sent off her kids on the school bus. It‚Äôs been a busy morning for her; she had woken up early to cook food for her husband and the two darling-turned-devils of her eyes. She returns upstairs and spends the rest of the morning preparing lunch for her kids who‚Äôll soon be home, arguing with her maid, and reminding the security guard for the umpteenth time to call a plumber to repair the leaky faucet in her kitchen. She watches a repeat of her favorite TV show on Star Plus for a while before going to the market and buying fresh vegetables and bread for the next day. The year 2019 | A technology-enabled morning in an aspirational Indian‚Äôs life The father sits down on the sofa in the living room, exhausted after an early morning run. He checks his Fitbit and grins as the tiny screen highlights that his mean speed was 25% higher than last month‚Äôs average. After freshening up, he wakes up the kids and walks over to the living room. While pouring milk and cereal into three bowls, he observes that the pack of cereals is almost empty. His kids enter the living room and call out to Alexa to play their customized playlist of morning songs, and she dutifully obliges. He whips out his phone, opens WhatsApp and video calls his better half who‚Äôs away on a business meeting. The happy family reunion is interrupted by the sound of the doorbell, which suggests that Amazon will timely deliver the new toy the younger kid had been demanding for the past week. The dad checks the time, gets dressed quickly, and books a cab while tying his shoes. He drops his kids off to school and orders their favorite pack of cereals on Grofers. He calculates that he has just about enough time to finish the Netflix special that he had dozed off while watching last night. The app‚Äôs proprietary algorithm that incessantly analyzes his viewing habit dutifully suggests a new range of TV Shows for him to binge-watch later. The world is generating a diverse range of data like never before. Over the last couple of years, 90% of the total data in the world has been generated. More than 3.7 billion people use the Internet today, and that number is only increasing. Google is processing more than forty thousand searches every second, while 41000 new pictures are being uploaded on Instagram every minute. By the time you‚Äôre done reading this paragraph, Uber riders would‚Äôve taken more than forty-five thousand trips! In this scenario, businesses have an unprecedented opportunity to capitalize on the vast amount of information they are gathering on their current as well as prospective customers. Social Media is analyzing the behavioral patterns of individual users and predicting their affinities with great accuracy. The entire world is moving towards a connected networking platform with the advent of the Internet of Things and Machine Learning techniques. Data has become the new oil, and Data Scientists and Analysts are expected to monetize this oil to the greatest extent possible. But this burgeoning sector is experiencing a shortage of an efficient workforce. The lack of data scientists has become a major constraint, and industries are clamoring for individuals who can make sense of the data they are amassing and provide tangible business advantages. There are a widening demand and supply gap in the market, and five years ago, IIM Calcutta, in conjunction with ISI Kolkata and IIT Kharagpur, had sought to capitalize on the mismatch. That‚Äôs how PGDBA was conceptualized, in accordance to the industry demands while paying due heed to their suggestions. As the fourth batch prepares to venture beyond the gates of Joka, the last one and a half years of training imparted at these stellar institutions are going to be employed. The industry has steep expectations of this bunch of talented individuals. They‚Äôre expected to draw meaningful insights out of data that benefits their businesses. From risk management to healthcare analytics, to behavioral analytics and digital marketing; the needs that PGDBA graduates are expected to cater to are diverse. As the world keeps amassing higher amounts of data, it‚Äôll become increasingly difficult to make sense out of it. It‚Äôll be akin to finding the precisely manufactured red coloured needle out of multiple piles of slightly deformed red coloured needles; surgical precision is critical to ensure it does not become a bloodbath. That‚Äôs where this course comes in, perfectly positioned to meet the business requirements by capitalizing on the technological advancements of the 21st century. Tags Analytics , Data Sciences , IIM Calcutta , IIT KGP , ISI , PGDBA , Student Life Categories About Us What is PGDBA? Post author By pgdba_admin Post date December 3, 2015 2 Comments on What is PGDBA? PGDBA stands for Post Graduate Diploma in Business Analytics ( PGDBA website ), probably the first two year full time course in India, jointly offered by Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta; Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata and Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur. PGDBA has been started with the philosophy that data is the new oil in this century. With an abundance of data, driving a business successfully and effectively is becoming a tricky aspect. Recent surveys suggest that big data could create $300 billion in value in healthcare alone each year; clever use of location data across industries could capture $600 billion in consumer surplus. Conversely, poor data management can cost up to 35% of a business‚Äôs operating revenue. While the possibility and ability to capture and store the ocean of data has grown up to overwhelming levels, but the right use of techniques to extract ‚Äòinformation‚Äô from these data sets has not been keeping pace with the demands of the industry, and there continues to be a worrying skill shortage across all sectors. More specifically saying, crunching data to generate necessary business insights requires a strong hold on Statistics, Technology and Business simultaneously. The requirement is so rare that the industry hardly sees individuals having the amalgamation of all of these three crucial skills in the domain of Business Analytics. To cater to this need, PGDBA has been built based on three pillars: Math and Statistics, Technology and Business, as clear from the expertise of the parenting institutes. This course offers four semester with an introductory pre-semester. It is true that two years is not adequate enough to generate data scientists and one can hardly scratch the surface of Machine learning and Data mining, but the unique combination of this course gives it a distinct identity which unravels endless opportunities to the participants: Financial analysis, Consultancy, PhD in Machine Learning, R&D, entrepreneurship to build data-driven startups‚Ä¶you name it! The Prologue ‚Äì 30 days at Joka The Tales of the Triumvirate Interview Experiences PGDBA 2025-27 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2024-26 Interview experiences PGDBA 2023-25 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2022-24 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2021-23 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2020-22 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2019-21 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2018-20 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2017-19 Interview Experiences PGDBA 2016-18 Interview Experiences Part-1 PGDBA 2016-18 Interview Experiences Part-2 Foreign Internships: Ambassadors of PGDBA PGDBA 2015-17 Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 2 PGDBA 2015-17 Interview Experiences ‚Äì Part 1 PGDBATalks AINA ‚Äì Magazine AINA ‚Äì 1.0 AINA ‚Äì 2.0 AINA ‚Äì 3.0 AINA ‚Äì 4.0 Resources FAQs Tweet Share Pin it The Tales of the Triumvirate June 18, 2020 pgdba_admin Campus Life , General 3 Comments Just when the screen prompted ‚ÄòThe End‚Äô, my cell phone gently buzzed with a long-awaited notification. Sitting there all cozy in the 6-9 show of Avenger‚Äôs- End Game, the last few moments were surely the emotional roller-coaster. The intense ending of the movie in contrast with the intimation on my selection for the prestigious PGDBA programme made it the quintessential end game. In the amalgamation of a multitude of emotions, there were the elements of concern that made me wonder how the two-year journey would pan out. Having been selected for such a reputed course, I was cognizant of the fact that I would get to meet numerous talents with unparalleled finesse. As today marks the successful one-year completion of my PGDBA journey, I would love to be the raconteur to share an account of my experiences till date. IIMC Bridge Lake IIMC Classroom Mesmerized by the pulchritude of the IIM Calcutta campus, I was all set to traverse the invigorating voyage. In the orientation week, I got acquainted with most of my batch mates and realized the level of diverse expertise each one possessed. It was followed by the ‚Äòordinary‚Äô classes at IIM, where, every minute seemed like an incessant race against time, all for the quest of managerial acumen. Pre-semester was like a trailer of a fervent flick. In the backdrop of quizzes, case-studies, assignments, and presentations, a funky fresher‚Äôs party came like rejuvenation. Organized by our seniors, the soir√©e provided a platform for showcasing extra-curricular abilities. The parade of variant talents made me acknowledge the multiple prowess, our PGDBA batches owned. With each day that passed by, the hues of pre-sem grew fonder, until the time when it was concluded with a grilling semester exam. CD Deshmukh Bhavan @ISI Birthdays @ISI Diwali @ISI ISI Farewell And in no time, we all were in ISI Kolkata , mecca of Mathematics. The contrast could easily be spotted. Every nook and corner emanated erudite vibes. However, the aura of the institute was pleasant and welcoming. The race here was with knowledge. The devotion and pursuit for learning appeared pristine, which was also shown by the top-notch professors in their readiness to impart wisdom while being compassionate and understanding, enlightening the students in all aspects. With a chunk of peers playing badminton, others peering at them from the top and a few busy with the bulk of assignments, it was at times difficult to decide the activity one really wished to engage in. Apart from juggling between classes and projects, the quest for analytics competence prompted most of us to participate in several Data Science and B-schools competitions, wherein the laudable performances brought laurels to PGDBA. On the social front, be it the magnificence of the Kolkata Durga Puja celebrations, the vigor in Diwali revelry by the entire batch, or just the joy in exploring the city markets, all these would be cherished for life. As the winter winds drew near, the snug yet strenuous ISI semester ended, with a heart-warming farewell and a challenging end-term exam. Main Building @IITKGP Nehru Museum @IITKGP Holi VGSOM Building And soon, with the commencement of the year 2020, we all arrived at the enormous premises of IIT Kharagpur , where the chase was after an efficient time-management. From cycling to the classes to evening strolls to Tech-Market, switching academic buildings between periods to settling into the morning 8 routine while enduring winters, it was quite grueling in essence. In the thick of a bustling semester, the splendor of the Spring Fest, marked by the vibrant live performances and a frolic atmosphere, rolled in like fresh air. This was soon diluted by an enervating mid-semester exam, that seemed boundless. This semester, brimming with tonnes of academic activities, got shadowed, by the swelling plight of the COVID-19 pandemic and as aftermath, it was switched to online mode. As we arrive closer to the completion of this semester, it can be unequivocally opined that this was the most exhausting, yet had its own tunes, to which our rhythms got harmonized. The course is undoubtedly pretty demanding, which sometimes makes you question the worth of all the efforts. But, in the midst of an ongoing semester, when you find the beaming faces and satisfied souls of seniors after securing tremendous placements, where the giants across the country were hell-bent on hiring in a bunch, you realize the influence the power of the triumvirate, the structure of the course and your efforts can create. In a nutshell, the journey so far has been enveloped in vivacity with enlightenment, camaraderie, and a rich set of cultures from all the three institutes, at its very core! ‚Äî Sugandha Ranjan Post navigation Next Article The mission of PGDBA Previous Article PGDBA Interview Experiences ‚Äì 2020-22 Related Articles Articles The mission of PGDBA By Anurag Malakar, PGDBA Batch-5 (2019-21) The year 2005 | A regular morning in a middle-class Indian‚Äôs life The middle-aged‚Ä¶ General FAQs Please go through the official website for the program to answer your basic queries: https://www.iimcal.ac.in/programs/pgdba 1) How do I apply‚Ä¶ About Us What is PGDBA? ‚ÄúWithout big data analytics, companies are blind and deaf, wandering out onto the web like deer on a freeway.‚Äù -‚Ä¶ Articles Wiser By A Semester Of Statistics - Himanshu Goyal The first step is the hardest. - Unknown When one first hears about the PGDBA course, the‚Ä¶ This Article Has 3 Comments Madhur Modi June 18, 2020 Reply Truly mesmerizing Shreshth Bhatt July 12, 2020 Reply Ma‚Äôam its such a wonderful and an enjoyable experiences you and your fellow mates had ‚Ä¶and you really have described it so aptly‚Ä¶ Shivam Singh July 27, 2020 Reply I was pretty shy to ask for help regarding this course but after reading this I so want to Can you help me out ?
